{{Infobox document |document_name = Constitution of Romania |image = |image_width = |image_caption = |date_created = 1922 - 1923 |date_ratified = 29 March 1923 |location_of_document = |writer = |signers = [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand I]] |purpose = Replace the [[1866 Constitution of Romania|1866 Constitution]] }}
The '''1923 [[Constitution of Romania]]''', also called the Constitution of Union, was intended to align the organisation of the state on the basis of universal male suffrage and the new realities that arose after the [[Union of Transylvania with Romania|Great Union]] of 1918. Four draft constitutions existed: one belonging to the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]], written with contributions from [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]]; one composed by R. Boilă at [[Cluj-Napoca|Cluj]], under the influence of the [[Romanian National Party]]; one by [[Constantin Stere]], representing the views of the [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]]; and a fourth by C. Berariu. Except for Stere’s proposal, which involved a unicameral legislature, proportional representation and popular consultation through the plebiscite, the other three were inspired (when it came to political organisation) by the [[1866 Constitution of Romania|1866 Constitution]]. The Liberals came to power in 1922 and managed to push through their own draft, which was approved 247-8 (with two abstentions) in the Chamber of Deputies on March 26, 1923, and the next day in the Senate, 137-2 (with two abstentions). It was published in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'' and came into force on March 29.
The constitution had eight titles and 138 articles, of which 76 came in their entirety from its predecessor. It enshrined the principles of popular sovereignty (exercised through representatives), separation of powers in the state, rule of law and decentralisation. Rights and freedoms for all citizens were recognised, regardless of ethnicity, language, religion or social class; the right to own property was guaranteed and, for the first time, the nationalisation of mineral deposits was provided for. The Kingdom of Romania was defined as a “unitary and indivisible national state”, with an inalienable territory. The state guaranteed freedom of expression and assembly, of conscience and of religion, and declared that “as the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]] is the religion of the great majority of Romanians it is the dominant church in the Romanian State, while the [[Romanian Church United with Rome, Greek-Catholic|Greek-Catholic Church]] has primacy before other faiths”.
Regarding state organisation, legislative power was entrusted to Parliament (Senate and Assembly of Deputies) and the King; executive power to the King, who delegated it to the Council of Ministers; and judicial power to the central and local judicial organs. The right to vote was expanded beyond the 1866 regulations: it was universal for all males, equal, direct, compulsory and secret, based on majority representation. The Assembly of Deputies was elected through universal suffrage, while the Senate comprised members elected by different electoral bodies (the Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Agriculture and Labour, and professors, all divided into separate colleges), and members by right: the heir to the throne; [[Metropolitan bishop]]s; diocesan bishops of the Orthodox and Greek-Catholic churches; heads of state-recognised religious bodies; the president of the [[Romanian Academy]]; former presidents of the Council of Ministers; former ministers with at least six years’ seniority; former presidents of either legislative chamber who held this function for at least eight ordinary sessions; former senators and deputies elected to at least ten legislatures, irrespective of their duration; former presidents of the [[High Court of Cassation and Justice (Romania)|High Court of Cassation and Justice]]; reserve and retired generals; former presidents of the National Assemblies at [[Chişinău]], [[Chernivtsi|Cernăuţi]] and [[Alba Iulia]], which proclaimed their respective provinces’ union with Romania in 1918.
A special section discussing the King provides that the throne should remain with the [[House of Hohenzollern]], “from male to male in order of primogeniture and with the perpetual exclusion of women and their descendants”. The King’s person was declared inviolable, and ministers had responsibility for his acts, as any act of the sovereign had to be countersigned by a minister, who then became responsible for it.
Although the constitution was very advanced and democratic in many respects, it also contained imperfections in the functioning of state institutions that made it easy to subvert democracy. For instance, the King appointed the president of the Council of Ministers, who then organised elections. The government was thus in a position to ensure that its party won a majority in the legislature. In a well-functioning democracy, a government represents the will of parliament and not vice versa, as generally happened in the [[interwar period]].
The 1923 Constitution was abrogated when its [[1938 Constitution of Romania|February 1938 successor]] came into force. It was then partly revived after the [[King Michael Coup]] of August 23, 1944, and definitively abrogated when Romania became a republic on December 30, 1947. During this latter period, in July 1946, the Senate was abolished—the only significant modification to the document.
==References== * Stoica, Stan (coordinator). ''Dicţionar de Istorie a României'', pp. 89–90. Bucharest: Editura Merona, 2007.
==External links== * [http://www.constitutia.ro/const1923.htm Text of the constitution]

Cultural magazine | company = | publisher = | firstdate = {{start date and age|1969}} | country = [[Lebanon]] | based = [[Beirut]] | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | website = | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Al-Hadaf''''' (''{{lang-ar|الهدف}}''), (''{{lang-en|The Target}}'') is a [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian]] weekly political and cultural magazine published in [[Lebanon]].{{cite web|author=Nezar Andary|title=Arab Journals Provide Rich But Neglected Sources for Study of Arab World|url=http://www.aljadid.com/content/arab-journals-provide-rich-neglected-sources-study-arab-world|work=Al Jadid Magazine|accessdate=21 September 2014}} ==History and profile== ''Al Hadaf'' was founded in [[Beirut]] in 1969{{cite book|title=Europa World Year|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C&pg=PA2614|accessdate=21 September 2014|year=2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-255-8|page=2614}} by [[Ghassan Kanafani]] as the political mouthpiece of the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] (PFLP),{{cite book|author=Philip Mattar|title=Encyclopedia of the Palestinians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GkbzYoZtaJMC&pg=PA275|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6986-6|page=275}} espousing a [[Marxist–Leninist]] version of [[pan-Arab]] [[Palestinian nationalism]]. Kanafani also served as the [[editor-in-chief]] of the weekly.{{cite news|author1=Jihad Al Khazen|title=Arafat and the dream of Palestine|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/views/2009/08/18/82150.html|accessdate=21 September 2014|work=Al Arabiya|date=18 August 2009}}{{cite web|author=Reem Haddad|title=In Memory of Ghassan Kanafani|url=http://beirut.indymedia.org/en/2003/07/392.shtml|work=Beirut Indy Media|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=20 July 2003}} In 1972, Kanafani was killed by a car bomb, but ''Al Hadaf'' remains in publication. The magazine is based in Beirut. ==See also== * [[List of magazines in Lebanon]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.alhadafmagazine.com/ ''al-Hadaf'' homepage] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hadaf, Al}} [[Category:1969 establishments in Lebanon]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1969]] [[Category:Lebanese magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Political magazines]] [[Category:Cultural magazines]] [[Category:Arabic-language magazines]] [[Category:Palestinian politics]] [[Category:Media in Beirut]] [[Category:Palestinian nationalism]] [[Category:Pan-Arabism]] [[Category:Marxist magazines]] [[Category:Palestinians in Lebanon]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Lebanon]] [[Category:Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]]

page.title: Alcohol-related traffic crashes in the United States

revision.comment: /* See also */ * [[Transportation safety in the United States]]
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} [[File:2014 Traffic Deaths Above 0.08 BAC.png|thumb|right|2014 Traffic Deaths due to crashes involving drivers at or above 0.08 BAC <ref>[https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/Publication/812231]</ref>]] '''Alcohol-related traffic crashes''' are defined by the [[United States]] [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) as alcohol-related if either a driver or a non-motorist had a measurable or estimated [[Blood alcohol concentration|BAC]] of 0.01 g/dl or above.<ref>[http://www.nhtsa.gov/people/injury/research/alcoholcountries/background_&_intro.htm]</ref>
This statistic includes any and all vehicular (including bicycle and motorcycle) accidents in which any [[alcohol]] has been consumed, or believed to have been consumed, by the driver, a passenger or a pedestrian associated with the accident. Thus, if a person who has consumed alcohol and has stopped for a red light is rear-ended by a completely sober but inattentive driver, the accident is listed as alcohol-related, although alcohol had nothing to do with causing the accident. Furthermore, if a sober motorist hits a drunk pedestrian, the accident is also listed as alcohol-related. Alcohol-related accidents are often mistakenly confused with alcohol-caused accidents. Some<ref> https://www.motorists.org </ref><ref> http://www.alcoholproblemsandsolutions.org/Controversies/1090948932.html </ref> have criticized the NHTSA for compiling this statistic since it may give the impression that drunk drivers cause a much higher percentage of accidents and does not accurately reflect the problem of [[drunk driving in the United States]].
Nationally, 31% of all drivers involved in fatal accidents during 2013 are known to have been [[Drunkenness|intoxicated]] according to the [[blood alcohol concentration]] (BAC laws) of their state.<ref>http://www.alcoholalert.com/alcohol-and-drunk-driving-articles.html</ref> This number is based on a systematic examination of the official records of each and every accident involving a fatality during that year in the US.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} However, a majority of fatalities resulting from car accidents involving alcohol are from sober drivers who are hit by drunk drivers.
The higher number (about 40%) commonly reported refers to accidents defined as alcohol-related as estimated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Each year, [[The Century Council]], a national non-profit organization funded by a group of [[Distillery|alcohol manufacturers]], compiles a document of alcohol-related traffic fatalities. Between 1991 and 2013, the rate of alcohol-related traffic fatalities (ARTF) per 100,000 population has decreased 52% nationally, and 79% among youth under 21.<ref>[http://centurycouncil.org/learn-the-facts/research#888 The Century Council's Research]</ref>
== See also == * [[Foundation for Advancing Alcohol Responsibility]], funded by a group of distillers * [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]] * [[Transportation safety in the United States]]

'''Araki Yasusada''' was a non-existent [[Japan]]ese poet, generally thought (though unverified) to be the creation of [[United States|American]] literature professor [[Kent Johnson]] (born 1955). The publication of Yasusada's poetry by major [[literary journals]] including the ''[[American Poetry Review]]'', ''[[Grand Street (magazine)|Grand Street]]'' and ''[[Conjunctions]]'' during the early 1990s created an embarrassing scandal for these publications.
== Araki's fictional biography == Araki Yasusada was supposedly a [[hibakusha|survivor]] of the [[Hiroshima]] atom bomb. He was born in 1907, attended [[Hiroshima University]] (before it was even founded, in 1949), worked in the postal service, and was conscripted into the Japanese army during [[World War II]]. He died of cancer in 1972. His son discovered his poems and notebooks and in 1991 they began to appear in print in the United States.
The 'notebooks' included editorial comments, smudged ink and illegible text, and other elaborate attempts to give the appearance of authenticity. They also included hints leading to their own unravelling, however, such as references to poets who probably would not be known to Japanese poets of the period and anachronistic references to such things as scuba divers.
== Kent Johnson == The real writer of the poems is widely believed to be [[Kent Johnson]], professor of [[Highland Community College (Illinois)|Highland Community College]] in [[Freeport, Illinois]], though he has never claimed authorship. Beliefs about Johnson's role as author stem in no small part from the fact that Johnson edited the Yasusada texts for the Wesleyan University Press. Johnson also included Yasusada's poetry in his doctoral dissertation.
The texts that had been published in the poetry journals were sent to various academics from a variety of locations, presenting Yasusada as an invented persona that was used by one or more people who intended the keep the origin of the texts secret.
Johnson admitted to some critics that Yasusada was nothing but an invented pseudonym "somebody" used to conceal the writer's origin. Some editors, who asked Johnson who the real writer was, claim to have received different answers. One response was that the real writer was "Tosa Motokiyu," one of the three "Japanese translators" — or at least, 95 percent of the poems were his, the rest being Johnson's older work, which Motokiyu had requested to include in his Yasusada fiction. Johnson continued to lecture on Yasusada and denied the hoax in interviews. At one stage he claimed that Motokiyu asked Johnson to take credit for the poems before Motokiyu's death. Yet elsewhere he said that Motokiyu's name was yet another pseudonym.
There were a number of rumors about other supposed co-authors, including the leading avant-garde Mexican composer, Javier Alvarez, who appears as co-editor of the work with Johnson. Publishers demanded their money back and criticized the hoax. Wesleyan cancelled the publication of the poetry collection. Some critics noticed that Johnson had published similar poetry in 1986 under the name of Ogiwara Miyamori, in ''Ironwood'' magazine.
== Criticism == After the 'hoax' was discovered, several journals rejected previously accepted poems. The hoax has allegedly been called "a criminal act" by Arthur Vogelsang, editor of ''American Poetry Review'', which had previously published a special supplement of Yasusada poems, including an alleged portrait of the author, but in letters to the ''[[Boston Review]]'' he denied having used the phrase.<ref>[http://www.bostonreview.net/BR22.3/Vogelsang.html]</ref> But numerous critics were supportive, praising both the conceptual nature of the fiction and the quality of the writing, including Roof Books that published the entire text in 1997.
==References== {{Reflist}}

''Tamkang Journal'' (2010)]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2015}} {{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = BW Summer Festival | image = File:BW Summer Festival Skinny Dip 2013.jpg | location = [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]], [[New Zealand]] | years_active= 2004–2014 | founded by = | dates = 27 December - 1 January | website = [http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/ www.bwsummerfestival.com] }}
'''BW Summer Festival''', (commonly known as '''BW''' or BayWatch), was an annual music festival that was held in [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]], [[New Zealand]].
==History== The festival began in 2004 as '''BW Campgrounds''',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/about-bw/ |title=ABOUT {{!}} BW Summer Festival |date=2015-04-03 |access-date=2017-02-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403114843/http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/about-bw/ |archivedate=3 April 2015 }}</ref> to help host the thousands of visitors visiting the district for the [[Rhythm and Vines]] New Year's Eve festival. BW operates a range of camping grounds hosting over 16,000 people each year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rhythmandvines.co.nz/faq/|title=FAQ|website=Rhythm and Vines|language=en-NZ|access-date=2017-02-17}}</ref>
In 2007, BW Summer Festival added the '''Jim Beam Sound Shell''' amphitheatre to host its own artists in the lead-up to Rhythm and Vines.
BW holds the [[Guinness World Record]] for the largest [[skinny dip]] event <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-skinny-dipping-(swimming-naked)|title=Largest skinny dipping (swimming naked)|newspaper=Guinness World Records|access-date=2017-02-17|language=en-GB}}</ref>
On the evening of 31 December 2014, a riot broke out at the campground between the two sectioned off campsites when some campers decided to set tents on fire and started throwing things at each other. It resulted in 68 arrests and 83 injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK1501/S00001/63-arrests-in-gisborne-bw-festival-riot.htm|title=63 Arrests In Gisborne BW Festival Riot {{!}} Scoop News|website=www.scoop.co.nz|access-date=2017-02-17}}</ref>
Since 2015 this festival has been merged with the [[Rhythm & Vines]] festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/|title=BW Summer Festival|website=www.bwsummerfestival.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-17}}</ref>
==Line-ups==
===2014/2015=== [[Flume (musician)|Flume]], [[Shapeshifter (band)|Shapeshifter]], [[David Dallas]], [[Peking Duk]], [[Sticky Fingers (band)|Sticky Fingers]], [[Home Brew (band)|Home Brew]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/line-up/2014-lineup-first-release/ |title=2014 LINEUP {{!}} BW Summer Festival |date=2015-04-03 |access-date=2017-02-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403105225/http://www.bwsummerfestival.com/line-up/2014-lineup-first-release/ |archivedate=3 April 2015 }}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} [[Image:Bush Ground Zero.jpg|thumb|President [[George W. Bush]] speaking at Ground Zero with Beckwith beside him]] '''Bob Beckwith''' (born September 21, 1933) is a retired member of the [[New York City Fire Department]]. He became well known to the United States' public after he stood next to President [[George W. Bush]] as the president gave a speech at the ruins of the [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]] after the attacks of September 11, 2001. Photos of Beckwith and the president appeared on the front page of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' and the cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine. This exposure launched him into the national spotlight and led to press attention and interviews. Beckwith has met several times with President Bush since then, spoken extensively in public, and acted as a fundraiser for charities.
==Family and career== Beckwith has lived for more than 50 years with his wife Barbara in the same house in [[Baldwin, Nassau County, New York]]. The couple has six adult children.<ref name=Yahoo1 /> Beckwith is a veteran of the [[New York City Fire Department]] with 30 years of service.<ref name=WSJ_AP1 />
==Actions at Ground Zero==
On the morning of September 11, 2001, Beckwith was tending to his grandson, who had been hit by a car while biking to school. Before he arrived at the hospital with his grandson, Beckwith was aware that a plane had struck the [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]]. When the boy appeared to be in stable condition, Beckwith left the hospital and went to World Trade Center site after he saw the South Tower collapse via television. Even though he had been retired for seven years from the [[New York City Fire Department]], he grabbed his old gear and [[Deception|bluffed]] his way past the blockades and barricades that had been set up and began helping with [[bucket brigade]]s and [[missing person]] searches.<ref name="Yahoo1"/>
{{wikisource|Ground Zero Bullhorn Speech}}On September 14, after Beckwith and some men had unearthed a [[fire engine]] buried in rubble from the fallen buildings, they tested its stability as a stand from which to speak, and a [[U.S. Secret Service|Secret Service]] agent ordered him to help President Bush onto the platform.<ref name="Yahoo1"/> Beckwith handed Bush a [[bullhorn]] with which to address the crowd of responders and workers<ref name="NYDN1"/> and was told to climb down by the Secret Service<ref name = "Yahoo1"/> and [[Karl Rove]],<ref name = "NYDN1"/> but Bush insisted that Beckwith stay with him.<ref name = "Yahoo1"/><ref name = "NYDN1"/><ref name="WPIX1"/> An image of Bush with Beckwith was featured the next day on the front page of the ''[[New York Daily News]]''.<ref name = "Yahoo1"/>
==National fame and activities since 9/11== A photo of Bush with Beckwith standing together was published two weeks later on the cover of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine, catapulting Beckwith to the national spotlight. Rejecting his new-found fame, he initially refused to speak to various news personalities and shows—[[Diane Sawyer]], the ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today Show]]'', and [[Rosie O'Donnell]]—though he eventually appeared on [[MSNBC]] and other news channels and programs.<ref name="Yahoo1"/>
Beckwith continues to be bashful about his fame,<ref name="WSJ_AP1"/> though an enlarged version of the ''Time'' magazine cover that made him famous hangs in his den.<ref name = "Yahoo1"/><ref name = "WSJ_AP1"/> Regarding the cover, Beckwith said that "[a]ll these guys that come over to interview me, they all have to have a picture of it." Beckwith also has a [[first edition]] print of the cover, which is encased in a display box together with a flag that waved at Ground Zero, given to him by President Bush. Beckwith has volunteered to have the items in his possession go to the 9/11 Memorial after he dies. He has already donated the clothes and helmet that he was wearing that day to the memorial.<ref name="Yahoo1"/>
Beckwith has visited 11 times with President Bush, traveled and spoken extensively,<ref name="Yahoo1"/> and dedicated much of his activity to fundraising for the [[New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation]].<ref name="Yahoo1"/><ref name = "WSJ_AP1"/>
On February 25, 2002, in a [[White House]] ceremony together with Governor [[George Pataki]] of New York state, Beckwith presented to Bush the bullhorn the president had used to address workers at the World Trade Center site just days after the attacks.<ref name = "NYDN1"/>
In the wake of the killing of [[Osama bin Laden]] by a team of [[United States Navy SEALs|U.S. Navy Seals]], Beckwith was asked his opinion. He stated: "I would have liked it to be on George Bush's watch, but it wasn't, so OK".<ref name = "WSJ_AP1"/> He also said: "But I'm glad we got him. He's burning in hell and he's going to rot there."<ref name = "WPIX1"/>

<ref name="WPIX1">{{cite news |url=http://www.wpix.com/news/wpix-firefighter-stood-with-bush-reacts-to-osama,0,5752728.story |title=Firefighter Who Stood With Pres. Bush At Ground Zero: Osama Is 'Burning In Hell' |first1=Mary |last1=Murphy |work=[[WPIX]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=September 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318050342/http://www.wpix.com/news/wpix-firefighter-stood-with-bush-reacts-to-osama%2C0%2C5752728.story |archivedate=March 18, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref>

Bush|date=September 2, 2011|accessdate=September 5, 2011|first1=Jess|last1=Wisloski|publisher=[[Yahoo News]]}}</ref> <ref name= "WSJ_AP1">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/AP3a37f40ca42b440782fc7302aaf5f652|title=AP Interview: Bullhorn firefighter's famous moment|author=Associated Press|work=Wall Street Journal|date=September 1, 2011|accessdate=September 5, 2011}}</ref> }}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} '''Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival''' is a local event occurring in various venues around Brighstone and Mottistone on the Isle of Wight in [[England]] for the winter tourist season.<ref> [http://www.islandpulse.co.uk/b2/brighstone-christmas-tree-festival-2009 Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312005630/http://www.islandpulse.co.uk/b2/brighstone-christmas-tree-festival-2009 |date=12 March 2011 }} Retrieved 15 July 2011</ref> This charitable event raises money for local and national charities<ref> [http://www.iwcp.co.uk/news/news/christmas-trees-galore-at-festival-30144.aspx "Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival." On the Wight.] Retrieved 15 July 2011 </ref> <ref> [http://www.events.onthewight.com/brighstone-methodist-church/brighstone-christmas-tree-festival "Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival."On the Wight.] Retrieved 15 July 2011 </ref>
==History== The Brighstone [[Christmas Tree]] Festival began in 1996 and has since been able to raise nearly £100,000 for Island and national charities. The festivities traditionally start on a Wednesday with a tree lighting ceremony in Brighstone Church in aid of the Earl Mountbatten Hospice. This event has attracts over 7,000 tourists each year.<ref> [http://www.iwcp.co.uk/news/news/brighstone-lit-up-for-tree-festival-42107.aspx "Brighstone lit up for tree festival." Isle of Wight County Press Online.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref>
In 2009, [[Sally Taylor (TV presenter)|Sally Taylor MBE]], anchor of BBC South Today, led the lighting of the “Tree of Joy” at the Brighstone Methodist Church and more recently Alan Titchmarsh was a guest of honour too.
==Locations== The annual festival is held at [[St. Mary's Church, Brighstone|St. Mary’s Church]], the Methodist Church, the Wilberforce Hall, the Social Club and the Three Bishops Pub in Brighstone, The Isle of Wight Pearl on the Military Rd and at [[St. Peter and St. Paul's Church, Mottistone|St. Peter and St. Paul’s Church in nearby Mottistone]]. A Park & Ride system is in place and operates from the Isle of Wight Pearl bringing people into Brighstone where a further shuttle service conveys people to Mottistone and back.<ref> [https://archive.is/20130722215043/http://www.islandpulse.co.uk/b2/brighstone-christmas-tree-festival-9097/ "Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival. " Island: Pulse: Isle of Wight News.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref>
Brighstone also has numerous attractions for visitors, including a church dating back to 1190 and a museum with a Victorian design.<ref> [http://www.aferry.co.uk/news/isle_of_wight_zoo_to_enter_christmas_tree_festival-18874551.htm "Isle of Wight Zoo to enter Christmas tree festival." aferry.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref>
==Festivities== The highlight of the celebration is the showcasing of over 200 theme decorated Christmas trees exhibited by charities, associations, businesses, families, and individuals.<ref> [http://www.redfunnel.co.uk/my-isle-of-wight/features/bright-lights-of-brighstone-christmas-tree-festival/ "Bright lights of Brighstone Christmas Festival".] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref> The festivities include carol services, military band concerts, choir singing, and the lighting of the hospice tree, which marks the beginning of the four-day event. There is also a [[Christmas]] gift and craft fair.<ref> [http://www.iwcp.co.uk/news/news/brighstone-lit-up-for-tree-festival-42107.aspx "Brighstone lit up for tree festival." Isle of Wight County Press Online.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref> Admission is free but donations are welcomed.<ref> [https://archive.is/20130722215043/http://www.islandpulse.co.uk/b2/brighstone-christmas-tree-festival-9097/ "Brighstone Christmas Tree Festival. " Island: Pulse: Isle of Wight News.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref>
==Entries== Entries are created and displayed by charities, clubs, schools, individuals, groups, and businesses, making this one of the biggest Christmas festivals in England.<ref> [http://www.iwradio.co.uk/articles/2012-12-05-christmas-tree-festival-set-to-bring-in-visitors "Christmas Tree Festival set to bring in visitors." Isle of Wight Radio News.] Retrieved 22 July 2013 </ref> In the west of the island, this is a major event and many locals contribute. The churches are decorated, and banners put up across the [[Back of the Wight]].
Many organizations, such as the [[National Health Service]], [[RSPCA]], and local charities, use their trees to give information, appeal for money, or raise awareness.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.womanalive.co.uk/News?newsaction=view&newsid=5773 Portsmouth: visitors flock to Christmas tree festivals] *[http://www.halesowennews.co.uk/newsxtra/travel/4717723.A_magical_Wight_Christmas/ Magical Wight Christmas] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130520121650/http://achristmasnearyou.com/ Official Website the Diocese of Exeter]

The '''BAC International Film and Video Festival''' is an [[independent film]] festival held in the borough of [[Brooklyn]] in [[New York City]] sponsored by the [[Brooklyn Arts Council]].
Established in 1966, the festival is the longest running event of its kind in Brooklyn. The selection groupings accepted and screened in the festival include work by independent, college student and youth (K-12) in both feature and short length. Categories are narrative, experimental, documentary, animation, and films by Brooklyn filmmakers and women of African descent.
The event is held at several venues including [[Brooklyn Arts Council]] office, [[Pratt Institute]], and [[Long Island University]].
== External links == * [http://www.brooklynartscouncil.org/ Brooklyn Arts Council main page]

'''Christiania Offentlige Theater''' ('Christiania Public Theatre') or ''Det Strømbergske Teater'' ('Strömberg Theatre') was a historic theatre in [[Oslo]] in Norway, active between 1827 and 1835. It was the first public theatre in Oslo and in Norway, and the predecessor of the [[Christiania Theatre]].
The theater was founded by the Swedish theatre director [[Johan Peter Strömberg]]. With the exception of the unsuccessfull attempt of [[Martin Nürenbach]] in 1772, there was no public theatre in Oslo or anywhere in Norway prior to 1827. Theatre was performed by foreign travelling theatre companies, or privately by ''[[Det Dramatiske Selskab]]''.
Strömberg wished to establish a professional public theatre in Norway, with professional native actors. He obtained a theater permit from the Danish crown, and founded the first dramatic school in 1825 in order to train the first group of native actors.
In 30 January 1827, the theatre was inaugurated with a performance of Strömberg's students, the pioneer group of Norwegian actors. However, the Norwegian actors was not considered trained enough to meet the standars of the audience, and Strömberg was forced to engage trained actors from Denmark. On 4 November 1827, Strömberg performed his play ''Fredsfesten'' in praise of the unpopular [[Swedish-Norwegian Union]], which attracted great criticism. In the spring of 1828, Strömberg was declared bancrupt, rented the theatre and the theatre permit to one of his Danish actors, [[Jens Lang Bøcher]], and returned to Sweden. Jens Lang Bøcher replaced almost all of the Norwegian staff with Danes, allowing only five Norwegians to remain. On 22 June 1832, Strömberg sold the theatre to the director [[Carl Anton Saabye]], after which it was renamed to Christiania Offentlige Theater.
The first opera performed in public in Norway, ''Deux mots'' by [[Nicolas Dalayrac]], was performed here in 1831, directed by [[August Schrumpf]] with [[Augusta Smith]] in the main role.<ref>{{cite web|last=Europas konstnärer|title=Schrumpf|url=http://runeberg.org/eurkonst/0532.html|publisher=Runeberg.org|accessdate=23 August 2011|language=no}}</ref>
The theatre burned down on 5 November 1835, after which the theater company performed in the house of the ''Det Dramatiske Selskab'' until the [[Christiania Theatre]] was inaugurated on 4 October 1837.
==References== {{Reflist}} * Blanc, Tharald Høyerup: ''[https://archive.org/stream/christianiatheat00blanuoft/christianiatheat00blanuoft_djvu.txt Christiania theaters historie 1827-1877]'', J.W. Cappelen Christiania * Næss, Trine. (2009, 13. februar). Johan Peter Strömberg. I Norsk biografisk leksikon. Hentet 11. september 2018 fra https://nbl.snl.no/Johan_Peter_Str%C3%B6mberg. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110724190120/http://www.wergeland2008.no/Articlelist.aspx?m=118&amid=615] * [http://www.folkedans.com/folkedans/stildans_christiania.htm] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110611210352/http://www.trondheim.com/content.ap?thisId=92936399] * Forhandlinger i Anledning det Forefaldne i Christiania offentlige Skuespilhuus den 4de November 1827, 1828

{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} [[Image:Chunee.jpg|thumb|An anonymous cartoon depicting Chunee's death, 1826]] '''Chunee''' (or '''Chuny''') was an [[Indian elephant]] who was brought to [[English Regency|Regency]] [[London]] in 1811. Three elephants were brought to England in [[East India Company]] ships between 1809 and 1811. The third of these was Chunee. He travelled on the [[East Indiaman]], {{ship||Astell|1809 EIC ship|2}}, from Bengal, arriving in England in July 1811. Grigson, Caroline, ''Menagerie: The History of Exotic Animals in England'', Oxford University Press, 2016. {{ISBN|9780198714705}}{{rp|190}} The other two elephants, also owned by [[Stephani Polito]] at some point, arrived in England in September 1809,{{rp|125}} and June 1810.{{rp|186}}
"Mr Polito ... has obtained possession of a remarkably fine Elephant, brought to England in the Hon. East India Company's ship, [[Winchelsea_(1803_EIC_ship)#EIC_voyage_#3_(1808–1809)|Winchelsea]], [[William_Moffat_(MP)#Captain_William_Moffat_(1774–1850)|Capt. William Moffat]], which will be exhibited at [[Romsey|Rumsey]] [sic] fair on Monday; and it is expected he will be offered for public inspection for a day or two, in this town {{bracket|[[Winchester]]}}, on his way to the Exeter 'Change London." ''Hampshire Chronicle'' (23 April 1810), p.4.
The second elephant was brought to England from [[Sri Lanka]] on the East India Company ship {{ship||Walthamstow|1789 EIC ship|2}} in June 1810.{{rp|186}} Chunee was originally exhibited at the [[Covent Garden Theatre]],{{rp|190}} but was bought by circus owner [[Stephani Polito]] to join his [[menagerie]] at [[Exeter Exchange]] on [[Strand, London|the Strand]] in London. The menagerie was bought by [[Edward Cross (zoo proprietor)|Edward Cross]] in 1817. The events in which the elephant was put to death in 1826 became a [[cause célèbre]]. ==Career== Chunee weighed nearly 7 [[ton]]s, was 11 feet tall, and was valued at [[pound sterling|£]]1,000. He was tame, and was originally a theatrical animal, appearing on stage with [[Edmund Kean]]. His plays included ''Blue Beard'', at the [[Theatre Royal, Covent Garden]], and the [[pantomime]] ''Harlequin and Padmanaba, or the Golden Fish'', at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]]. Chunee was trained to take a [[British sixpence coin|sixpence]] from visitors to the menagerie to hold with his [[Elephant#Trunk|trunk]] before returning it. An entry in [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]]'s journal records a visit to Exeter Exchange on 14 November 1813, when "The elephant took and gave me my money again — took off my hat — opened a door — trunked a whip — and behaved so well, that I wish he was my butler." ==Death== Chunee became dangerously violent towards the end of his life, attributed to an "annual [[wikt:paroxysm|paroxysm]]" (perhaps his [[musth]]) aggravated by a rotten [[tusk]] which gave him a bad [[toothache]]. On 26 February 1826, while on his usual Sunday walk along the Strand, Chunee ran amok, killing one of his keepers. He became increasingly enraged and difficult to handle over the following days, and it was decided that he was too dangerous to keep. The following Wednesday, 1 March, his keeper tried to feed him [[poison]], but Chunee refused to eat it. Soldiers were summoned from [[Somerset House]] to shoot Chunee with their [[musket]]s. Kneeling down to the command of his trusted keeper, Chunee was hit by 152 [[Musket#Ammunition|musket balls]], but refused to die. Chunee was finished off by a keeper with a [[harpoon]] or [[sword]]. The floor of his cage was deeply covered with his blood, and it was said that the sound of the elephant in agony was more alarming than the reports of the soldiers’ guns. ==Aftermath== [[File:Chunees Skelett.jpg|thumb|Chunee's skeleton]] Hundreds of people paid the usual [[shilling]] entrance fee to see his carcass butchered, and then dissected by doctors and medical students from the [[Royal College of Surgeons of England|Royal College of Surgeons]]. His [[skeleton]] weighed 876 lb (397 kg), and was sold for £100 and exhibited at the [[Egyptian Hall]] in [[Piccadilly]], and later at the Royal College of Surgeons in [[Lincoln's Inn Fields]], the bullet holes clearly visible. His skin weighed 17 [[hundredweight|cwt]] (1,900 lb or 860 kg), and was sold to a [[Tanning (leather)|tanner]] for £50. Chunee's skeleton was on display in the Hunterian Collection until 1941 when it had a direct hit from a [[Luftwaffe]] airstrike. The manner of Chunee's death was widely publicised, with illustrations printed in popular [[broadsheet|newssheet]]s of volley after volley being shot into his profusely bleeding body. Recipes were published for elephant stew, along with [[Sentimentalism (literature)|maudlin]] poems saying "Farewell, poor Chuny". Letters were printed in ''[[The Times]]'' protesting at the barbarity of the process, and the poor quality of the living conditions of the animals in the menagerie. The [[Zoological Society of London]] was founded in April 1826. The controversy was the inspiration for a successful play at [[Sadler's Wells]], entitled ''Chuneelah; or, The Death of the Elephant at Exeter 'Change''. The menagerie at Exeter Exchange declined in popularity after Chunee's death. The animals were moved to [[Surrey Zoological Gardens]] in 1828, and the building was demolished in 1829. ==See also== *[[List of historical elephants]] *[[Topsy the Elephant]] *[[Tyke (elephant)|Tyke]] *''[[Shooting an Elephant]]'' ==Sources / further reading== * *{{cite book|last=Donald|first=Diana|title=A divided nature : the representation of animals in Britain, c.1750-1850|year=2007|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|isbn=0300126794|pages=171–173|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WeaZhKkL9YwC&lpg=PA340&ots=VMbTO7Uw9_&dq=Chuneelah%3B%20or%2C%20The%20Death%20of%20the%20Elephant%20at%20Exeter%20'Change.&pg=PA171#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060926125224/http://www.blackburn.gov.uk/server.php?show=ConWebDoc.7127 Medal of Chunee] at Blackburn Museum *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050715071127/http://www.exetersystems.com.au/beswick/beswick05/ExeterExchange.htm Exeter Exchange] *[http://www.dickinson.edu/~nicholsa/Romnat/zoos.htm Romantic Rhinos and Victorian Vipers: The Zoo as Nineteenth-Century Spectacle] by Ashton Nichols *[http://www.ph.ucla.edu/epi/snow/1859map/cross's_menagerie_a2.html Cross's Menagerie] (includes links to contemporary images) *[http://www.victorianlondon.org/entertainment/collegeofsurgeons.htm Royal College of Surgeons] at Victorian London *[http://www.virtualmuseum.info/collections/object.asp?galleryid=108&ckid=4991&row=7&desc=2 Ceramic] depiction of Chunee in [[Stephani Polito]]'s Menagerie *[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/images/B003RJ58K8/ref=dp_image_0?ie=UTF8&n=11052681&s=kitchen ''Destruction of the Furious Elephant of Exeter Change''] (Lithographic print dated 6 March 1826) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314000556/http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/collections/object.php?object_id=390 ''Destruction of the Noble Elephant''] (Hand coloured print) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090204181329/http://www.counterpunch.org/hribal12142006.html ''When Animals Resist their Exploitation''] by Jason Hribal {{Commons category}} ==References== {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} The '''Collaborators Act''' was a law enacted in 1972 by the [[government of Bangladesh]] to try those who did not side with the nationalist cause in the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]], or politically opposed the liberation war or willingly cooperated with the [[Pakistan Army]] or committed criminal acts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trial of crimes against humanity could come under Collaborators Act: Suranjit |url=http://www.banglanews24.com/English/detailsnews.php?nssl=b0ab42fcb7133122b38521d13da7120b&nttl=201108283332 |newspaper=BanglaNews24 |date=7 August 2010 |accessdate=2013-07-12 |quote="On 24 January 1972, the government of Bangladesh enacted another law to try those who did not side with the liberation war or politically opposed the call of liberation war or willingly cooperated with the Pakistan Army or committed criminal acts."}}</ref> This law is referred as the '''Bangladesh Collaborators (Special Tribunal) Order 1972''', commonly known as Collaborators Act, 1972.
About 2,884 cases were filed under this law until October 1973. Of the accused, 752 were given punishment.<ref>{{cite news |script-title=দালাল আইন ফিরছে |trans-title=Collaborators Act returns |url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/print_edition/?view=details&archiev=yes&arch_date=16-12-2010&type=gold&data=news&pub_no=371&cat_id=1&menu_id=13&news_type_id=1&index=0#.Ud4AKNululQ |newspaper=Kaler Kantho |language=bn |date=16 December 2010 |accessdate=2013-07-12 |quote="১৯৭৩ সালের অক্টোবর পর্যন্ত এই আইনের আওতায় দুই হাজার ৮৮৪টি মামলা দায়ের করা হয়। এসব মামলায় সাজা দেওয়া হয় ৭৫২ জনকে।"}}</ref> Later on 31 October 1975, the Collaborators Act was dismissed due to several reasons and irregularities found in the law. The law was amended three times.
The Act, was designed to facilitate arrest and trial of accomplices as well as of local perpetrators of the genocide remained in place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Fotoes/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals..%A8%A8/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals.htm |title=Report on the Findings of the People's Inquiry Commission on the Activities of the War Criminals and the Collaborator |publisher=Forum for Secular Bangladesh |date=26 March 1994 |accessdate=2013-07-13 |quote="The 1972 Collaborators Act, designed to facilitate arrest and trial of accomplices as well as of local perpetrators of the genocide remained in place." |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415235114/http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Fotoes/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals..%A8%A8/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals.htm# |archive-date=15 April 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Background== What happened in Bangladesh between 25 March and 16 December 1971 epitomized the spirit of the human will as well as man's unlimited capacity to be brutal towards fellow men. Rarely in the history of mankind have a people displayed so much heroism and suffered so much pain within the space of so short a time as the people of Bangladesh did.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Fotoes/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals..%A8%A8/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals.htm |title=Report on the Findings of the People's Inquiry Commission on the Activities of the War Criminals and the Collaborator |publisher=Forum for Secular Bangladesh |date=26 March 1994 |accessdate=2013-07-13 |quote="What happened in Bangladesh between March 25 and December 16, 1971 epitomized the spirit of the human will as well as man's unlimited capacity to be brutal towards fellow men. Rarely in the history of mankind have a people displayed so much heroism and suffered so much pain within the space of so short a time as the people of Bangladesh did." |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415235114/http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Fotoes/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals..%A8%A8/Report%20on%20the%20war%20criminals.htm# |archive-date=15 April 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
During this war some Bengali civilians took the side of Pakistani Army of occupation. They collaborated the army to occupy the whole Bangladesh and supported the atrocities committed by them.
The members of [[Pakistan Muslim League]], [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami|Jamaat-e-Islami]], [[Nizam-e-Islam]] joined the [[East Pakistan Central Peace Committee|Peace Committee]], which was actually formed to support the atrocities. A dummy cabinet was formed under Nurul Amin in which Abul Kashem, Nawajesh Ahmed, AKM Yousuf, Abbas Ali Khan, Maolana Ishak joined. Obaydullah Mazumder, an [[Awami League]] leader also joined in the cabinet. After liberation 46 MNAs from Awami League was denounced or relegated from the party.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rokomari.com/book/15576;jsessionid=317EF55864FB1ADEA97114612EA40365 |title=বাংলাদেশের শাসন ব্যবস্থা ও রাজনীতি -ড. আবুল ফজল হক |publisher=Rokomari.Com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> On the other hand, under the supervision of [[Pakistani Army]] another force named [[Razakars (Bangladesh)|Rajakar]] was formed to replace the Ansar. Jamaat-e-Islami leader AKM Yousuf, with 96 members of Jamaat-e-Islami started a training camp in Khulna Ansar and VDP camp to fight against the freedom fighters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boi24.com/muktizuddher-prekkhapote-byktir-obosthan.html |title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধের প্রেক্ষাপটে ব্যক্তির অবস্থান : Online Book Shop in Bangladesh : Pay After You Get : 24/7 |publisher=Boi24.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Most of the Rajakar personnel were the members of Jamaat-e-Islami
[[Al-Shams (Bangladesh)|Al-Shams]] and [[Al-Badr]] was also formed in order to counter the guerrilla activities of the [[Mukti Bahini]] which grew increasingly organised and militarily successful during in the second half of 1971. All three groups operated under Pakistani command.
On this regard, [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] on his repatriation in Bangladesh on 10 January 1972, declared to try the collaborators along with the Pakistani Army who committed genocide and atrocities.<ref name="prothom-alo">{{cite news|script-title=যুদ্ধাপরাধীদের বিচার ও বাস্তবতা |trans-title=War criminals trial and reality |url=http://www.prothom-alo.net/V1/archive/news_details_mcat.php?dt=2007-11-13&issue_id=427&cat_id=3&nid=Njg0NDU=&mid=Mw |newspaper=[[Prothom Alo]] |language=bn |date=13 November 2007 |accessdate=2013-07-12 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Genesis== The process to try the collaborators during the first days of Bangladesh was not going through any legal process. People were angry and were killing the collaborators without any trail. These activities tarnished the overall image of the nation. Some were being killed because of personal issues. So a government was forced to create a law and begin a trial to pacify the agitation.
===Law=== The Bangladesh Collaborators (Special Tribunals) Order, 1972 was announced to try the local war criminals. On 24 January 1972 an order came in effect.
The constitution of Bangladesh was also amended to include Article 47 (3) in order to fasten the trial of members "of any armed or defence or auxiliary forces" for genocide, crimes against humanity or war crimes. In addition, The International Crimes (Tribunals) Act, 1973 was announced on 20 July 1973 mainly to try the Pakistani war criminals.
The government also announced a two-tier trial process where national and international jurists would be appointed to try some high-profile war criminals, while an all-Bangladeshi jurist panel would try the rest.
=== Statements of the government === Many statements were provided by the responsible officials of the government of Bangladesh regarding this issue.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman on his arrival on 10 January 1972 ensured that the collaborators will be tried along with their Pakistani masters. But he also asked his people to give the responsibility to the government<ref name="hritkalom.blogspot">{{cite web |author= |url=http://hritkalom.blogspot.com/2010/09/blog-post.html |script-title=হৃৎ কলম: একাত্তরের ঘাতক ও দালালেরা কে কোথায় |trans-title=Who and where are war killers and collaborators |date=27 February 2004 |language=bn |website=Hritkalom |type=Blog |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Sheikh Mujibur Rahman ordered Awami League leaders to gather proof against the collaborators and assured that the collaborators will be tried for times and again. On 12 January 1972, Rahman addressed people, saying that the criminals will not go unpunished under his government.<ref name="scribd_a">{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/109505431/%E0%A6%8F%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4-%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%98%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%95-%E0%A6%93-%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A5%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AF |script-title=একাত্তরের ঘাতক ও দালালরা কে কোথায় |trans-title=Where are the killers and agents of war |language=bn |website=Scribd}}</ref>
Mujib on 14 January asked the Awami League activists not to take revenge and assured that legislative measures will be taken against the collaborators in time.<ref name="scribd_a" />
On 30 March, in a public gathering in Chittagong he asked the people should he pardon the collaborators or not. The people of Chittagong said, "No and never".<ref name="scribd_a" />
==Implementation== The implementation of the law started on 15 February when an order signed by secretary Taslimuddin Ahmed was circulated stating that 14 top collaborators have to surrender. The list was made addressing [[Nurul Amin]], [[Ghulam Azam]],<ref>{{cite news |title='I was on list of collaborators' |first1=Manik |last1=Julfikar Ali |last2=Laskar |first2=Rizanuzzaman |date=14 May 2012 |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=234062 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> Khan A Sabur, [[Shah Azizur Rahman]], Maulana Muhammad Ishaq, Khawaja Khayeruddin, Mahmud Ali, AKM Yousuf,<ref name="bdnews24">{{cite news |title=Jamaat leader Yusuf arrested |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/05/12/jamaat-leader-yusuf-arrested |newspaper=bdnews24 |date=12 May 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> Abbas Ali Khan and many others as collaborators.<ref name="prothom-alo" /> Awami League leader Obaydullah Mazumder of Feni was among the list of the collaborators.
Later some 50,000 collaborators were arrested under the act.<ref name="prothom-alo" /> Among them 752 were found guilty and was punished.
About 37,471 cases were filed under this law till October 1973. On 28 March 73 tribunals were formed to try the collaborators. It was also declared that other courts will refrain from the cases under these tribunals.
===Sentences=== About 2,884 cases were solved and the verdict was given under this law till October 1973 before the general amnesty was declared by Mujib. Only 752 of them were found guilty and only one of them was sentenced capital punishment. As many as two thousand were acquitted after the trial.<ref name="scribd_a" /> * On 10 February 1973 life imprisonment was sentenced against Maulana Muhammad Ishaq for collaboration.<ref name="prothom-alo_a">{{cite news |script-title=৭৫২ যুদ্ধাপরাধীর সাজা হয়েছিলো |trans-title=752 war criminals were sentenced |url=http://www.prothom-alo.net/V1/archive/news_details_mcat.php?dt=2008-03-26&issue_id=875&cat_id=1&nid=OTA0OTg=&mid=MQ== |newspaper=[[Prothom Alo]] |language=bn |date=26 March 2008 |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref>
Two Jamaat-e-Islami leader AKM Yousuf and Abbas Ali Khan were arrested under the law. After the war, Yousuf was sentenced to life imprisonment under the 1972 Collaborator’s Order.<ref name="bdnews24" />
Sa'ad Ahmed, a leader from Kushtia was sentenced life imprisonment for supporting the atrocities as a [[East Pakistan Central Peace Committee]] member and taking part in the election of 1971.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
Chikon Ali, a Rajakar from Mirpur of Kushtia was sentenced to death on 10 June 1972, which was the first ever verdict of capital punishment under the law. The punishment of Chikon Ali was later cut short by the Supreme Court to life imprisonment.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
An absentia trial staged under the law gave death penalty to three Al-Badr members for the murder of prominent Professor Dr. AK Azad on 6 October 1972.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" /> The culprits were never found.
On 11 April 1972, Rajakar Abdul Hafiz of Comilla was sentenced 41 years imprisonment, highest in the history of this law. He was tried for various convictions like murder, rape, loot etc.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
In the July 1972, three brothers of Bogra were given punishment as Nurul Islam of same area filed a murder case them. Mofizur Rahman aka Chan Miah was sentenced to death, Mokhlesur Rahman aka Khoka Mia and Moshiur Rahman aka Lal Miah were sentenced to life imprisonment. After appealing against their punishment Chan Miah was sentenced to 20 years imprisonment while his two brothers were sentenced to 10 years imprisonment both.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
Keramat Ali of Munshiganj was sentenced to 8 years imprisonment because of his activity as a Peace Committee member.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
A special tribunal sentenced Mokbul Hossain, Ayub Ali and Atiar Rahman to life imprisonment on the Montu murder case.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
Al-Badr members Siddiqur Rahman and Muhammad Galib were sentenced life imprisonment on the journalist Nizamuddin murder case.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" />
==Criticism== The Collaborators Act 1972 was a flawed law with many defects. It was amended for at least three times within one year. Many criticised the law because of its defects and irregularities.
===Unaccepted=== The pro-Awami League researcher Shahriar Kabir in cross examination confessed that the trials occurred under this act were never accepted by the families of the martyrs.<ref name="banglanews24">{{cite news |script-title=জামায়াত নেতাদের স্বাক্ষরিত পরিচয়পত্র বহন করতো রাজাকাররা: শাহরিয়ার কবীর |trans-title=Jamaat leaders would carry an identity card signed rajakarara: Shahriar Kabir |url=http://www.banglanews24.com/detailsnews.php?nssl=718726592600dd79284f1812d9685dce&nttl=20120910070123138009 |newspaper=Banglanews24.com |date=10 September 2012 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
Shahin Reza, son of famous journalist Shirajuddin Hossain stated that, the trial of the collaborators was nothing but a kangaroo trial<ref name="hritkalom.blogspot" /> to protect the collaborators. Those who were involved in murders and genocides were set free and the innocents were imprisoned without substantial proof.<ref name="scribd_a" />
Khaleque Mazumder, who killed Shahidullah Kaiser was sentenced to only a seven years imprisonment under the act. Panna Kaiser, the widow of Shahidullah Kaiser marked it as a humiliation of humanity and justice.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kaiser |first=Panna |date=1991 |title=Muktijuddha: agey o paray |script-title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ: আগে ও পরে |trans-title=War of Liberation: Before and After |language=bn |location=Dhaka |publisher=Agamee Prakashani |isbn=984-401-004-7}}</ref>
===Politicization=== Prominent political leaders and intellectuals like Maolana Bhashani, Abdur Rashid Tarkabagish, Abul Mansur Ahmed, Justice S M Morshed, Alim AL Razy, Enayetullah Khan, Ataur Rahman Khan and many others started criticizing the law because of the abusive measures.<ref name="prothom-alo" />
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman himself started facing problems while the process to try the collaborators begun. The Awami League leaders and activist getting order from Mujib to submit genocide data started to misusing the power. They started to use the power against their personal foes.
On the other hand, many political parties and its members were convicted of collaboration with Pakistanis. So many of them started criticising the steps taken by the government because of political benefit.
===Legal problems=== [[File:বাংলাদেশ দালাল অধ্যাদেশ ১৯৭২, ঘাতকদের রক্ষাকবচ.png|thumb|বাংলাদেশ দালাল অধ্যাদেশ ১৯৭২, ঘাতকদের রক্ষাকবচ]] The Collaborators Act faced major legal problems as it was created in a very short time. Barrister Moinul Hossain, an Awami League backed Member of Parliament criticized the law in an article published in [[The Daily Ittefaq]] on 19 November 1972.<ref name="prothom-alo" />
Barrister Moinul Hossain stated: {{quote|According to the first schedule of the legislation, under the Collaborators Act the collaborators will remain out of the purview of principal rights of a citizen. The conflict between Collaborators Act and principal rights is now ascertained. No indication of the time of the offence in the law will be misused by many. According to the law, just because of an accusation according to any hearsay can suspend the principal rights of an innocent citizen.<ref name="prothom-alo" />}}
On the other hand, this law had a provision in its section 7 which stated that the conviction against the criminals will come in effect only if the Officer in Charge of the Police of that particular area certify that as an offence.<ref name="hritkalom.blogspot" /> According to the act, No cases can be filed in the tribunal if the Officer in Charge defies.<ref name="hritkalom.blogspot" />
Many police officers took the side of the Pakistani Government during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]]. And most of the families of the collaborators were enough solvent to pay a good margin to police officers. So police officers were not enough conscious about these cases.
Another defect was that the act gave the convicts an opportunity to appeal against the verdict while the victims were not given such opportunity.
On 23 July 1972 in an article published on Dainik Bangla some experts stated that, {{quote|The tribunals are trying the crimes occurred in a certain period which was actually an emergency one. But still the authority is following the ancient 'Evidence Act' which was actually created to try the offences occurred in the time of peace. While investigating the cases, it is becoming hard to harder to prove it because of the complexities arising.<ref name="hritkalom.blogspot" />}}
Prominent writer [[Ahmed Sharif]], [[Shahriar Kabir]] stated the Collaborators Act 1972 as a '''safeguard''' to the collaborators and war criminals.
Later during a cross examination on 10 September 2012, Shahriar Kabir confessed that the International Crimes Tribunal Act 1973 was created to overcome the problems of the Collaborators Act 1972.<ref name="banglanews24" />
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was also concerned about the failures of the Collaboration Act 1972.<ref name="prothom-alo" /> The call of general amnesty in 1973 was somehow influenced because of his concern about this law.<ref name="prothom-alo" />
==Flawed process== The Collaborators Act 1972, soon started to prove itself as a spiderweb. The number of big flies trapped in it were very low. Dr. Malik, Maulana Muhammad Ishaq, AKM Yousuf, Izhar Ahmed were the only big figures to be punished.<ref name="prothom-alo_a" /> Many others who were directly involved in genocide were freed or went underground.
[[File:Shah Aziz Freed.jpg|thumb|Shah Aziz Freed]] The uncle of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, Sheikh Mosharraf Hossain was a Rajakar.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=132023286996853&set=vb.155230181301463&type=3&theater |title=Reconciliation-এ জোর দিয়েছিলেন খোদ শেখ মুজিবই |publisher=Channel I |language=bn |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> He sent him to jail. But soon many such cases started to arise.
Awami Muslim League leader Rajakar Athar Ali Khan was the father of a freedom fighter from Bagerhat who attained the gallantry award [[Bir Uttam]] for his bravery.<ref name="Murshid2010">{{cite book |last=Murshid |first=Ghulam |date=2010 |title=Muktiyuddha o tārapara: ekaṭi nirdalīẏa itihāsa |script-title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ ও তারপর একটি নির্দলীয় ইতিহাস |trans-title=The Liberation War and then: A non-partisan history |language=bn |location=Dhaka |publisher=Prathamā Prakāśana |isbn=978-984-8765-37-1}}</ref> Athar Ali Khan did not face any trial because of his son.
A Rajakar who later joined Bangladesh Rifles (Presently known as [[Border Guards Bangladesh]]) after liberation war remained untouched and promoted in a higher post during Sheikh Mujibur Rahman regime.<ref name="Murshid2010" />
Taslimuddin Ahmed, who signed the notification for the 14 collaborators asking them to surrender was himself a collaborator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rokomari.com/book/5190;jsessionid=876C738183626C2AD133D4DE1BA79600 |title=পঁচাত্তরের রক্তক্ষরণ-মেজর রফিকুল ইসলাম পিএসসি |publisher=Rokomari.Com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Another surprising scenario was staged in a special tribunal where a Rajakar recruiting officer became the judge and gave verdict against the one whom he recruited as Rajakar.<ref name="Murshid2010" /> Many such situations was raised that time.
Those who had close relation with Sheikh Mujibur Rahman were never tried. Mujib himself freed collaborators like Khan A Sabur,<ref>{{cite news |last=Maksud |first=Syed Abul |date=5 November 2013 |script-title=সৌজন্যবোধ ও বাঙালির কথাবার্তার কথা |trans-title=Bengalis of speech and human kindness |url=http://www.prothom-alo.com/opinion/article/65518/%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%99%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%A5%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%A5%E0%A6%BE |newspaper=Prothom Alo |language=bn}}</ref> [[Shah Azizur Rahman]], Wahiduzzaman, Mawlana Abu Zafar Mohammad Saleh, former Awami League leader AKM Shamsul Haque and many others.<ref name="Momen1980">{{cite book |last=Momen |first=Nurul |date=1980 |title=Bangladesh, the First Four Years: From 16 December 1971 to 15 December 1975 |publisher=Bangladesh Institute of Law & International Affairs |oclc=499570532}}</ref>
After liberation war, a committee was formed under Nilima Ibrahim to find out the collaborators who worked in Radio Pakistan. 43 people were found by the committee who worked for Pakistan. Unfortunately no action were taken against them as they were the part of progressive society as well as Awami League and some of them were killed by Pakistanis.
Lieutenant Colonel Firoz Salahuddin, who recruited many Rajakar and was loyal to the Pakistan Army till the end of liberation war was rehabilitated in the [[Bangladesh Army]] after the liberation war for having close relation with [[M. A. G. Osmani]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rokomari.com/book/1861;jsessionid=3FFF2D7659D67C5A5971DB9E4912725B |title=একাত্তরের মুক্তিযুদ্ধ, রক্তাক্ত মধ্য আগষ্ট ও ষড়যন্ত্রময় নভেম্বর -কর্ণেল শাফায়াত জামিল (অব.) |publisher=Rokomari.Com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
==General amnesty== As the second anniversary of victory in the Bangladesh Liberation War approached, most of those jailed under the Collaborators Act had been detained for nearly two years without being charged with specific crimes.<ref name="Kabir 2001">{{cite book |last=Kabir |first=B. M. Monoar |chapter=The Politics of Religion: The ''Jamaat-i-Islami'' in Bangladesh |date=2001 |editor-last=Ahmed |editor-first=Rafiuddin |title=Religion, Identity & Politics: Essays on Bangladesh |publisher=International Academic Publishers |pages=124 |isbn=978-1-58868-081-5 |quote="Withdrawal of the Collaborators' Act was prompted by a number of considerations. In the first place, the government generally failed to bring specific charges against most of them ... another very important agenda: to create a favorable climate for improving relations with the countries of the oil-rich Muslim Middle East. Faced with mounting economic problems at home, and foreign reserves reduced to zero, Bangladesh was desperately looking for support from the Muslim countries."}}</ref><ref name="wfp">{{cite news |title=Bangladesh Govt. Grants Amnesty |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/profile/worldbruce-wikipedia/clipnumber/27068/ |newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press |date=8 December 1973 |page=69}} {{open access}}</ref> It was proving difficult to obtain sufficient evidence for prosecution. Villagers were reluctant to testify because of fear of retaliation. Also public sentiment had grown less concerned with punishing collaborators and more worried about the shattered economy.<ref name="Sundar1974" /> The continued imprisonment of alleged collaborators and threat of legal action against those not yet arrested was increasingly viewed as an attempt to silence political opposition.<ref name="wfp" /> It was having the opposite effect by creating fresh social tensions.<ref name="Sundar1974">{{cite news |last=Sundar |first=Ram |date=23 July 1974 |title=Bangladesh: Release of political prisoners termed 'a risk' |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4364399/bangladesh_release_of_political/ |newspaper=The Ottawa Journal |agency=Canadian Press |page=48 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=19 February 2016}}{{Open access}}</ref>
In addition to domestic considerations, there were international ones. In August 1973, the [[Delhi Agreement]] had started the repatriation of prisoners of war, but two significant issues remained. First, Bangladesh wanted Pakistan to accept hundreds of thousands of [[Stranded Pakistanis in Bangladesh|Biharis]] who had remained loyal to Islamabad during the war, still considered themselves citizens of Pakistan, and didn't want to live in the now independent Bangladesh. Second, Bangladesh wanted 195 Pakistani POWs tried for war crimes. Sheik Mujib desired diplomatic recognition by Pakistan and membership in the United Nations, something China was blocking at the behest of her ally Pakistan.<ref name="wfp" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan bars Bangladesh from UN over prisoners |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=886&dat=19730922&id=_rpaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TVADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4508,15257&hl=en |newspaper=The Prescott Courier |location=Prescott, AZ |agency=Associated Press |date=21 September 1973 |page=2 |access-date=19 February 2016}}</ref> Bangladesh also sought more favorable relations with the oil-rich Muslim Middle East in the hope that foreign aid would be forthcoming.<ref name="Kabir 2001" />
In this climate, Sheik Mujib announced on 1 December 1973 a general amnesty for 36,400 alleged collaborators. The pardon did not extend to the few thousand prisoners charged with wartime murder, rape, or arson.<ref name="wfp" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Islam |first=Sirajul |year=2012 |chapter=Collaborators Tribunal Order (1972) |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Collaborators_Tribunal_Order,_1972 |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref>
===Declaration=== The declaration was depicted in the newspapers on 1 December 1973. ''Dainik Bangla'' stated the news with the headline, "General Amnesty Declared upon the Punished Prisoners under Collaborators Act".<ref>{{cite news |title=752 Were Punished |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/153281570/752-Were-Punished |newspaper=Prothom Alo |language=bn |date=26 March 2008 |via=Scribd |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> The newspaper said,
{{quote|Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh has declared a general mercy for the convicted and punished prisoners under the Collaborator Act. Persons who have been imprisoned under the Collaborator Ordinance (Special Tribunal) 1972, against whom there is a warrant or those who are wanted and those who have been punished will be imposed this general mercy and soon they will be freed. Yet those who have killed people, raped and set fire or caused to damage people's homestead with explosives or convicted for damaging water-transport whatsoever will not be considered under this act. A Governmental press-note issued on Friday night last says this General amnesty.<ref name="icsforum">{{cite web |url=http://icsforum.org/blog/admin/bangabandhu%E2%80%99s-general-amnesty-declaration-evidential-documents-and-relevant-stories/ |title=Bangabandhu's 'General Amnesty' Declaration: Evidential Documents and Relevant Stories |date=24 July 2010|website=International Crimes Strategy Forum Blog |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623180039/http://icsforum.org/blog/admin/bangabandhu%E2%80%99s-general-amnesty-declaration-evidential-documents-and-relevant-stories/ |archive-date=2012-06-23 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>}}
It added that, {{quote|Prime Minister Sheikh Mujibur Rahman says, Government has declared this general mercy for the people arrested and convicted under Collaborator Act so that people from all corners can enjoy the Victory Day 16th December together indiscriminately and take oath to build our country. Bangabandhu has ordered the Home Ministry to take necessary steps so that these persons can get released from Jail soon and join the victory festival coming on 16th December. The persons freed are urged to be united with spirit of victory and are requested to take the responsibility of working as a safeguard for our independence.<ref name="icsforum" />}}
As a result of the amnesty, 21,000 prisoners were released on 17 December 1973.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh National day display |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131699092 |newspaper=The Canberra Times |agency=AAP-Reuter |date=18 December 1973 |page=6 |access-date=20 February 2016 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Many prominent collaborators were freed after the declaration gradually.
Khwaja Khairuddin, who was the chief of the Peace Committee was freed from jail on 7 December 1973.<ref name="Momen1980" /> Khairuddin was jailed for life by the tribunals.
Muslim League leader Khan A Sabur was freed from jail on 5 December 1973.<ref name="Momen1980" />
Shah Azizur Rahman, Wahiduzzaman, Mawlana Abu Zafar Mohammad Saleh, former Awami League leader AKM Shamsul Haque, AKM. Yousuf, Abbas Ali Khan and many others got freed after the declaration.
Among them AKM Yousuf and Khwaja Khairuddin were sentenced to life imprisonment.<ref>http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x18c3fk_akm-yousuf-xvid</ref>
==Repeal of the law== After the fall of Mujib on 15 August 1972 and unfortunate killing of four top leaders from Bangladesh Awami League, an ordinance was declared which halted the activity under this act. Later on President [[Abu Sadat Mohammad Sayem]] repealed the act on 31 December 1975. This gave the lackeys of Pakistani occupational force a complete legal protection from farther facing any kind of trial.
===Text of the ordinance=== Whereas it is expedient to repeal the Bangladesh Collaborators (Special Tribunals) Order, 1972 (P.O. No. 8 of 1972), and to provide for certain matters ancillary thereto;
Now, Therefore, in pursuance of the Proclamations of 20 August 1975, and 8 November 1975, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-
1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Collaborators (Special Tribunals) (Repeal) Ordinance, 1975.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/sections_detail.php?id=510&sections_id=13422 |title=1.Short title |date=31 December 1975 |website=Legislative and Parliamentary Affairs Division |publisher=Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> 2. # (1) The Bangladesh Collaborators (Special Tribunals) Order, 1972 (P.O. No. 8 of 1972), hereinafter referred to as the said Order, is hereby repealed.<ref name="bdlaws.minlaw" /> # (2) Upon the repeal of the said Order under sub-section (1), all trials or other proceedings thereunder pending immediately before such repeal before any Tribunal, Magistrate or Court, and all investigations or other proceedings by or before any Police Officer or other authority under that Order, shall abate and shall not be proceeded with.<ref name="bdlaws.minlaw" /> # # (3) Nothing in sub-section (2) shall be deemed to affect - # (a) the continuance of any appeal against any conviction or sentence by any Tribunal, Magistrate or Court under the said Order; or # (b) except to the extent provided in that sub-section, the operation of section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 (X of 1897).<ref name="bdlaws.minlaw">{{cite web |url=http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/sections_detail.php?id=510&sections_id=13423 |title=2.Repeal of P.O. No. 8 of 1972 |date=31 December 1975 |website=Legislative and Parliamentary Affairs Division |publisher=Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
===Bibliography=== * {{Citation |last=Murshid |first=Ghulam |authorlink=Ghulam Murshid |date=2010 |title=Muktiyuddha o tārapara: ekaṭi nirdalīẏa itihāsa |script-title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ ও তারপর একটি নির্দলীয় ইতিহাস |trans-title=The Liberation War and then: A non-partisan history |language=bn |location=Dhaka |publisher=Prathamā Prakāśana |isbn=978-984-8765-37-1}}. * {{Citation|last=Halim |first=Abdul|authorlink= Abdul Halim|title=সংবিধান, সাংবিধানিক আইন ও রাজনীতি|year=1995|publisher=CCB Foundation|oclc=458320182|trans-title=Constitution, Constitutional Law and Politics|pages=540|nopp=yes|edition=6th|ignore-isbn-error=true|url=http://202.74.245.18/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=3084&shelfbrowse_itemnumber=43972}}. * {{Citation|last=Ahmed Sharif|first=Shahriar Kabir|authorlink=Ahmed Sharif|title=একাত্তরের ঘাতক দালালরা কে কোথায়|year=1987|publisher=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ চেতনাবিকাশ কেন্দ্র|trans-title=War is a killer}} * {{Citation|last=Maksud |first=Syed Abul|authorlink=Syed Abul Maksud|title=অরন্য বেতার|year=2010|publisher=প্রথমা|isbn=978-984-8765-62-3|trans-title=The Jungle Radio|language=Bengali}}. * {{Citation|last=Kaiser |first=Panna|authorlink=Panna Kaiser|title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ, আগে ও পরে|year=1991|publisher=আগামী|isbn=984-401-004-7|trans-title=War of Liberation: Before and After|language=Bengali}}.
