revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[File:2008 Singapore Grand Prix Renault Nelson Piquet Jr crash.jpg|thumb|right|The wrecked [[Renault R28]] car driven by [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] at the centre of the controversy]]
The '''Renault Formula One crash controversy''', dubbed '''Crashgate''' by some in the media,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6842843.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Renault given two-year suspended ban in Crashgate hearing | first=Ben | last=Smith | date=21 September 2009 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3e671f34-a69e-11de-bd14-00144feabdc0.html|title=Renault handed two-year suspended sentence for ‘Crashgate’|work=Financial Times|location=London|first=Roger|last=Blitz|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2013}}{{paywall}}</ref> is a [[sporting scandal]] perpetrated by the [[Renault F1]] team who [[team orders|ordered]] [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] to crash deliberately during the [[2008 Singapore Grand Prix]], to gain a sporting advantage for his Renault teammate [[Fernando Alonso]].<ref name="Piquetwinlibelcase">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/9265296.stm|title=Nelson Piquet Jr and his father win Renault libel case|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 December 2010|accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref>
On 28 September 2008, on the 14th lap of the Singapore race, the [[Renault R28]] driven by Piquet crashed into the circuit wall at turn 17, necessitating a [[safety car]] deployment. The other Renault driver, [[Fernando Alonso]], had previously made an early pitstop, and was promoted to the race lead as other cars pitted under safety car conditions. Alonso subsequently won the race after starting 15th on the grid. Piquet described his crash at the time as a simple mistake.
After being dropped by the Renault team following the [[2009 Hungarian Grand Prix]], Piquet alleged that he had been asked by the team to deliberately crash to improve the race situation for Alonso, sparking an investigation of Renault F1 for race fixing by [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] (FIA), the Formula One governing body. After an investigation, Renault F1 were charged with conspiracy on 4 September, and were to answer the charge on 21 September 2009.
On 16 September Renault stated that they would not contest the charges, and announced that the team's [[managing director]], [[Flavio Briatore]], and its [[executive director]] of [[engineering]], [[Pat Symonds]], had left the team.
On 21 September it was announced that the Renault F1 team had been handed a disqualification from Formula One, which was [[Suspended sentence|suspended]] for two years pending any further comparable rule infringements. Briatore was suspended from all Formula One events and FIA-sanctioned events indefinitely, whilst Symonds received a five-year ban.<ref name="f1ban">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8266090.stm|title=Renault handed suspended F1 ban|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="release">{{cite web|url=http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/wmsc/2009/Pages/wmsc_210909.aspx |title=FIA Press Release |work=Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004081125/http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/wmsc/2009/Pages/wmsc_210909.aspx |archivedate=4 October 2009 }}</ref> Their bans were subsequently overturned by a French court, although they both agreed not to work in Formula One or FIA-sanctioned events for a specified time as part of a later settlement reached with the governing body.<ref name="Courtoverturns">{{cite news|last=Noble|first=Jonathan|title=Court overturns Briatore's F1 ban|publisher=Haymarket Publications|work=autosport.com|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/80743|date=5 January 2010|accessdate=5 January 2010}}</ref><ref name=settlement>{{cite news|last=Elizalde|first=Pablo|title=FIA, Briatore reach settlement|publisher=Haymarket Publications|work=autosport.com|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/82844|date=12 April 2010|accessdate=12 April 2010}}</ref>
==Background==
===Renault F1=== [[File:Nelson Angelo Piquet.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Nelson Piquet Jr.]], December 2007]] The [[Renault F1]] Formula One team came into existence with the car manufacturer [[Renault]]'s re-entrance into Formula One in 2000, by purchasing the [[Benetton Formula One]] team. Italian businessman [[Flavio Briatore]] had been managing director of Benetton until 1997, when he was replaced by [[Prodrive]] boss [[David Richards (racing)|David Richards]]. After managing Renault's motorsport sister company [[Mecachrome]], he returned to the main team following the Renault takeover, again as managing director. In addition to his Formula One sporting interests, as of August 2007, Briatore was Chairman and part owner of the English [[association football|football]] club [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]] (QPR), which he purchased jointly with Formula One president [[Bernie Ecclestone]], being joined later by funds from Indian industrialist [[Lakshmi Mittal]].<ref name="Footbal League Briatore">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8260661.stm|title=Football League looks at Briatore|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
Spanish racing driver [[Fernando Alonso]] had been involved in Formula One since 2001, and drove for the team from [[2002 Formula One season|2002]] to [[2006 Formula One season|2006]]. After becoming World Champion in 2005 and 2006 and a one-year stint with [[McLaren]], he returned to the team in 2008. English engineer [[Pat Symonds]] had risen to his position as Executive Director of Engineering with Renault F1 having worked for the Benetton team, and having entered Formula One with Benetton's predecessor [[Toleman|Toleman Motosport]] in the early 1980s. Brazilian racing car driver [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] – son of the Formula One triple-world champion [[Nelson Piquet]] – joined the Renault F1 team as the second car driver alongside Alonso for the 2008 season, having been their reserve and test driver during 2007. Since October 2006, Piquet Jr. was also personally contracted to Flavio Briatore's management company FFBB.<ref name=Times18Sep09PiquetSrLegal>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6839589.ece|title=Nelson Piquet Sr to begin court fight against Flavio Briatore|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|first1=Anushka|last1=Asthana|first2=Jill|last2=Sherman}}</ref> Before the Singapore incident, Renault F1 had not won a race for almost two years (the last Grand Prix won was on 8 October 2006, the [[2006 Japanese Grand Prix|Japanese Grand Prix]]), and were said to be close to quitting the sport.<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09QnA/>
===2008 Singapore Grand Prix=== {{Main|2008 Singapore Grand Prix}} [[File:2008 Singapore Grand Prix podium.jpg|thumb|left|Alonso on the podium of the 2008 Singapore Grand Prix, with Briatore far right (white shirt)]] {{wikinews|Fernando Alonso wins 2008 Singapore Grand Prix}} The [[2008 Singapore Grand Prix]] was the fifteenth race of the [[2008 Formula One season]], and took place on 28 September 2008. The race was Formula One's first night race.<ref name=BBC17Sep09Blame/> On the race weekend, despite Alonso being close to the top in practice, Renault had a poor qualifying session and started well down the grid, with [[Fernando Alonso]] starting in fifteenth place, and [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] alongside him in 16th. Alonso was eliminated during qualifying because of mechanical failure.
After the race started, Alonso was the first driver to make a routine [[pit stop]] for fuel and tyres on lap 12, rejoining the race at the back of the field.<ref name=Guardian4Sep09>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/sep/04/formula-one-renault-crash-hearing-fia |title=FIA charges Renault over Nelson Piquet Jr crash in Singapore|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Maurice| last=Hamilton|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref> He had put in a light fuel load at the start of the race in an attempt to pass the cars in front of him; most drivers that qualify in low positions tend to do the opposite and go for heavier fuel loads to make one less pit stop (approximately 30 seconds each in terms of time loss) than the leaders, as they do not want to waste a light car and an extra pit stop for a faster car that is stuck behind slower vehicles. Three laps later, Nelson Piquet Jr. hit the circuit wall at turn seventeen, one of the turns on the circuit which did not have a crane nearby, necessitating the deployment of the [[safety car]].<ref>http://sportgeza.hu/forma1/2009/09/10/a_17-es_kanyarban_utkozz_ott_nincs_daru/</ref>
[[File:Felipe Massa 2008 Algarve.jpg|thumb|right|Brazilian [[Felipe Massa]] was leading the Grand Prix for [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] before Piquet Jr.'s crash]] Safety car regulations in 2008 meant that the pit lane was closed until all cars had been bunched up behind the safety car. Hence the advantage of the lead cars would be eliminated before they were able to pit and after they did pit, they would re-enter the race at the back of the field. Alonso, having pitted just before the safety car was introduced, therefore gained a significant advantage. (Under previous regulations, the pit lane remained open during safety car incidents and the lead cars could quickly pit before their lead was eliminated and re-enter the race with less loss of track position.) In order to avoid running out of fuel, some drivers did need to pit while the pit lane was closed and they were penalised for the infraction.
Most of the leading cars ended up behind Alonso and also behind some slower drivers who proved difficult to pass on the narrow circuit; those ahead of Alonso were lighter on fuel and whilst they were able to pull away, they still needed to make a pit stop. After gaining the lead in the final third of the race, Alonso went on to win the race.
{{quote|A first podium of the season and first victory as well and I am extremely happy. I cannot believe it right now, I think I need a couple of days to realise we won a race this year. It seems impossible all through the season to be close to the top guys and here suddenly we have been competitive from Friday. Obviously we started at the back and the first safety car helped me a lot and I was able to win the race.|[[Fernando Alonso]] after the race, his first win of the year.<ref name="pressconference">{{cite web|url=http://www.grandprix.com/race/r800sunpc.html|title=Singapore GP – Sunday – Press Conference|work=GrandPrix.com |publisher=Inside F1, Inc.|date=28 September 2008|accessdate=6 September 2009}}</ref>}}
{{quote|From the start of the race things were complicated and I had a lot of [[Graining (motorsport)|graining]] and the situation got worse and worse. The team asked me to push, which I tried to do and finally I lost the rear of my car. I hit the wall heavily but I'm OK. I am disappointed with my race but obviously very happy for the team this evening.|[[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] after the race.<ref name=Times18Sep09PressRelease/>}}
No action was initially taken over the crash. Piquet Jr. initially characterised the crash as a simple mistake.<ref name=BBC17Sep09Blame/> In the post-race press release from Renault F1, the team described Alonso's performance as a "brilliant tactical drive", while both Briatore and Symonds attributed the safety car use as a case of good luck.<ref name=Times18Sep09PressRelease>{{cite news|url=http://timesonline.typepad.com/formula_one/2009/09/a-load-of-utter-rubbish-from-renault-after-a-complicated-night-for-nelson-piquet.html |title=A load of utter rubbish from Renault after a "complicated" night for Nelson Piquet |publisher=[[The Times]] |work=Formula One Blog |first=Ed |last=Gorman |date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=18 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922183617/http://timesonline.typepad.com/formula_one/2009/09/a-load-of-utter-rubbish-from-renault-after-a-complicated-night-for-nelson-piquet.html |archivedate=22 September 2009 }}</ref> Following the race, freelance Formula One journalist [[Joe Saward]], writing on grandprix.com, stated that "some cynics" were questioning the incident, but dismissed it with the opinion that "one likes to believe that no team would ever be so desperate as to have a driver throw his car at a wall".<ref name=Times18Sep09PressRelease/><ref name=GPdotcomRaceReport>{{cite web|url=http://grandprix.com/gpe/rr800.html|title=Grand Prix Results, Singapore GP, 2008|publisher=grandprix.com|work=GP Encyclopedia, Races|date=28 September 2008|accessdate=18 September 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jshvtCaF?url=http://grandprix.com/gpe/rr800.html|archivedate=18 September 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the Brazilian television station [[Rede Globo]], Brazilian driver [[Felipe Massa]], who finished the Singapore race in 13th having been leading at the time of Piquet Jr.'s crash, and eventually lost the 2008 World Championship to [[Lewis Hamilton]] by one point, did question Briatore about the crash at the time, although FIA president [[Max Mosley]] stated the sport could take no action based on "speculation".<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09QnA>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/renault/6199480/Q-and-A-why-Renault-face-race-fixing-allegations-and-other-questions.html|title=Q and A: why Renault face race-fixing allegations and other questions|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009|location=London|first=Tom|last=Cary}}</ref>
===Piquet Jr. leaves Renault=== {{wikinews|Formula One: Renault dismisses Piquet, Schumacher barred from practising}} [[Fernando Alonso]] ended the 2008 season fifth in the Drivers Championship with 61 points, while [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] finished in twelfth place, with 19 points. Their collective total earned [[Renault F1]] fourth place in the Constructors Championship. Despite rumours that he was set to leave the team, Renault re-signed Piquet Jr. on a one-year contract for the [[2009 Formula One season|2009 season]], once again alongside Alonso.<ref name=Telegraph3388038>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/3388038/Fernando-Alonso-and-Nelson-Piquet-to-stay-with-Renault-in-2009-Formula-One.html |title=Fernando Alonso and Nelson Piquet to stay with Renault in 2009|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2009|location=London|first=Simon|last=Arron|date=5 November 2008}}</ref> By the tenth race of the [[2009 Formula One season|2009 season]], Piquet Jr. had failed to score any points whereas Alonso had managed 13 for the team. On 3 August 2009, Piquet confirmed that he had been dropped by Renault. The departure was acrimonious, with Piquet Jr. criticising his former Renault F1 team and Briatore.<ref name=Autosport77538>{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/77538|title=Angry Piquet confirms Renault exit|publisher=Haymarket Publications|work=autosport.com|first=Pablo|last=Elizalde|date=3 August 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref>
==Piquet's accusations==
===Initial reports and investigation=== {{wikinews|Reports suggest probe into Formula One race-fixing allegations}} On 30 August 2009, reports by the Brazilian television station [[Rede Globo]] stated that Nelson Piquet Jr. was ordered to crash during the Singapore race.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/aug/31/renault-f1-singapore-gp-nelson-piquet-junior|title=Renault may quit Formula One over new cheating claim|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Maurice|last=Hamilton|date=31 August 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009}}</ref> Formula One's governing body, the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] (FIA), immediately announced it was investigating "alleged incidents at a previous F1 event".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8229787.stm |title=F1 launches Singapore race probe|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=31 August 2009}}</ref> It was widely reported that the race in question was the Singapore 2008 race.
===Renault charged=== {{wikinews|Renault charged with Formula One race fixing}} On 4 September, following the investigation by the FIA, Renault F1 were formally accused of interfering with the outcome of the 2008 Singapore race and conspiring with Piquet Jr.<ref name=Guardian4Sep09/> In a statement, the FIA stated that the charges against Renault F1 included "a breach of Article 151c of the International Sporting Code, that the team conspired with its driver, Nelson Piquet Jr, to cause a deliberate crash at the 2008 Singapore Grand Prix with the aim of causing the deployment of the safety car to the advantage of its other driver, Fernando Alonso."<ref name=Autosport4Aug09>{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/78321 |title=Renault summoned by FIA's WMSC|publisher=Haymarket Publications|work=autosport.com|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref> The team was called to a meeting of the [[FIA World Motor Sport Council]] in Paris on 21 September, days before the 2009 running of the Singapore Grand Prix.<ref name=Guardian4Sep09/> After being charged, the Renault F1 team stated that they would be making no comments until the hearing.<ref name=Autosport4Aug09/>
===Leaked evidence=== On 10 September, Piquet Jr. made the second of two statements to the FIA.<ref name=Times11Sep09LegalAction/> On the same day, a [https://web.archive.org/web/20091001201052/http://www.f1sa.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17075&Itemid=219 transcript] of Piquet Jr's first statement to the FIA made at their Headquarters in Paris on 30 July was published by F1SA.com (the F1 Supporters Association).<ref name=Eurosport>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/10092009/23/transcript-nelson-piquet-jr-statement-fia.html |title=Transcript of Nelson Piquet Jr's statement to the FIA |publisher=''Yahoo! Eurosport UK & Ireland'' |accessdate=17 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915193657/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/10092009/23/transcript-nelson-piquet-jr-statement-fia.html |archivedate=15 September 2009 }}</ref> In response to questions over its authenticity, the FIA president Max Mosley stated "I haven't seen anything which I believe to be a forgery."<ref name=Times11Sep09Immunity/> In the transcript, Piquet Jr. states that he was asked by Briatore and Symonds to crash his car at a specific corner.<ref name=Times11Sep09LegalAction/> Alonso denied knowing of any plan to ask Piquet to crash, stating "I cannot imagine these things, these situations. It's something that never entered my mind."<ref name=BBC8249246>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8249246.stm |title=Alonso 'surprised' by fix claim |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=10 September 2009}}</ref> Nelson Piquet Jr. questioned whether Alonso knew that a crash was planned, citing that in his place, he would have questioned Renault's "senseless" Alonso race strategy of starting with a low fuel load and making an early [[pit stop]] on the twelfth lap.<ref name=Telegraph18Sep09AlonsoPiquetSnr>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/6203772/Singapore-crash-Nelson-Piquet-Snr-takes-step-back-from-Fernando-Alonso-allegation.html|title=Singapore crash: Nelson Piquet Snr takes step back from Fernando Alonso allegation|work=The Telegraph|location=London|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|first=Tom|last=Cary}}</ref> During the course of the investigation and before the WMSC hearing, Alonso was absolved of any blame by the FIA.<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09QnA2/> On 11 September, Max Mosley, the FIA president confirmed Piquet Jr. would face no action after making his two statements, even if the case was found in favour of Renault.<ref name=Times11Sep09Immunity>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6830875.ece|title=Nelson Piquet Jr granted immunity from prosecution in Renault 'crash-gate' scandal|work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|first=Tom|last=Dart|date=11 September 2009}}</ref>
===Renault start legal action=== [[File:Flavio Briatore Chinese GP 2008.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Briatore at the Chinese Grand Prix, 2008]] {{wikinews|Renault F1 launch criminal complaint against former driver over race-fixing allegation}} On 11 September, the day after Piquet Jr.'s statement to the FIA was leaked, Renault F1 stated that it intended to take legal action against Nelson Piquet Jr and his father in both French and British courts, stating that "...today the ING Renault F1 Team and its managing director Flavio Briatore personally wish to state they have commenced criminal proceedings against Nelson Piquet Jr and Nelson Piquet Sr in France concerning the making of false allegations and a related attempt to blackmail the team into allowing Mr Piquet Jr to drive for the remainder of the 2009 season".<ref name=Times11Sep09LegalAction>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6830499.ece|title=Renault to start legal action against Nelson Piquet Jr over crash claims|work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|first=Tom|last=Dart|date=11 September 2009}}</ref> In response to the legal action, Piquet Jr. stated "Because I am telling the truth I have nothing to fear, whether from the Renault team or Mr Briatore – and while I am well aware of the power and influence of those being investigated, and the vast resources at their disposal, I will not be bullied again into making a decision I regret".<ref name=BBC8250436>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8250436.stm |title=Renault to launch Piquet lawsuit|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=11 September 2009}}</ref>
On 14 September 2009, Pat Symonds was also reported to have been offered immunity from action if he provided the FIA with details of the alleged conspiracy.<ref name=Guardian15Sep09Transript>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/sep/15/flavio-briatore-renault-singapore-nelson-piquet-transcript |title=Singapore transcript reveals Flavio Briatore's anger at Nelson Piquet |work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=15 September 2009}}</ref> Symonds was reported to have told FIA investigators that the initial idea of a crash had come from Piquet Jr.<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09QnA2>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/renault/6203686/Qand-A-what-will-be-the-fallout-from-the-Renault-Fomula-One-race-fixing-scandal.html|title=Q&A: what will be the fallout from the Renault Fomula One race-fixing scandal?|work=The Telegraph|location=London|date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=18 September 2009|first=Tom|last=Cary}}</ref>
On 15 September, ''The Times'' newspaper published extracts of Renault F1 radio conversations transmitted before and after the Singapore race between Renault F1 personnel including Piquet Jr., Alonso, Symonds and Briatore.<ref name=Guardian15Sep09Transript/><ref name=Times6835442>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6834552.ece |title=‘Nelson Piquet Jr’s had a crash. It’s huge. Is he all right? Is he all right?|work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=15 September 2009|first=Edward|last=Gorman}}</ref>
===Briatore and Symonds depart Renault=== {{wikinews|Renault F1's team boss, top engineer quit as team accepts cheating claim}} On 16 September the Renault F1 team announced it would not be contesting the charges at the meeting of the FIA World Motor Sport Council in Paris on 21 September, and stated that both Briatore and Symonds had left the team.<ref name=BBC16Sep09RenaultStatement>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8258987.stm|title=Briatore out over Renault fix row|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=16 September 2009}}</ref>
{{quote|The ING Renault F1 Team will not dispute the recent allegations made by the FIA concerning the 2008 Singapore Grand Prix.
It also wishes to state that its managing director, Flavio Briatore and its executive director of engineering, Pat Symonds, have left the team.|[[Renault F1]] statement, 16 September 2009<ref name="RenaultStatement16Sep09">{{cite web|url=http://www.ing-renaultf1.com/en/_2009/team/index.php#/team/newsdesk/communiques/|title=ING Renault F1 Team Statement – 16 September 2009|publisher=ING Renault F1|date=16 September 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090921033111/http://www.ing-renaultf1.com/en/_2009/team/index.php#/team/newsdesk/communiques/|archivedate=21 September 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>}}
The FIA confirmed that 21 September meeting would still go ahead following the departure of Briatore and Symonds, with sanctions against Renault F1 still possible.<ref name=BBC16Sep09RenaultStatement/> The day after the Renault announcement, Renault confirmed Briatore had resigned from the team, while Briatore himself stated of his departure that "I was just trying to save the team", "It's my duty. That's the reason I've finished."<ref name=Times17Sep09Pelata/><ref name=SkySporst17Sep09BriatoreStatement>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12433_5565218,00.html|title=Briatore: I did it for Renault|publisher=Sky Sports|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref>
==World Motorsports Council meeting== The extraordinary meeting of the World Motorsports Council took place on 21 September 2009 in Paris. After a ninety-minute hearing, the council imposed a disqualification on Renault, [[suspended sentence|suspended]] for two years. This meant that if a similar incident occurred before 2011, Renault would be banned from Formula One. Briatore was banned indefinitely from any FIA-sanctioned event, while Symonds received a five-year ban. Furthermore, Briatore was indefinitely banned from managing drivers when the FIA stated that [[superlicence]]s would not be issued or renewed to any driver associated with him in the future. Alonso was cleared of wrongdoing; the FIA found no evidence that he or his mechanics knew anything about the scheme.<ref name="f1ban"/><ref name="release"/><ref name="Noble">{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/78770|title=Renault given two-year suspended ban|first=Jonathan|last=Noble|work=autosport.com|publisher=Haymarket Publications|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref>
The council came down hard on Briatore because he denied his involvement despite overwhelming evidence. Symonds, in contrast, had confessed, expressing his "eternal regret and shame" for his role in the scheme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2009/9/9954.html|title=FIA hands individual punishments to Briatore and Symonds|publisher=Formula One|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2009}}</ref> In announcing the sanctions, the council stated that Renault's actions were serious enough to merit being thrown out of Formula One altogether. However, it opted to impose a suspended sentence because Renault took swift action in forcing Briatore and Symonds to resign.<ref name="Noble"/> ''[[The Daily Mirror]]'' described the ''de facto'' lifetime ban on Briatore as the harshest sanction ever imposed on an individual in the history of motorsport.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2009/09/21/crashgate-renault-owner-flavio-briatore-slapped-with-lifetime-f1-ban-115875-21690293/|title=Renault owner Flavio Briatore slapped with lifetime F1 ban|first=Byron|last=Young|work=The Daily Mirror|location=London|date=21 September 2009|accessdate=21 September 2009}}</ref>
A major contribution to the punishment of Briatore and Symonds was the testimony of the unnamed "Witness X", a Renault employee who was also present at the pre-race meeting but rejected the idea. [[The Daily Mail]] has reported that Witness X was [[Alan Permane]], the team's chief [[race engineer]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/formulaone/article-1215794/Queens-Park-Strangers-F1-chief-Bernie-Ecclestone-says-Flavio-Briatore-ban-harsh--longer-talks-him.html|last=McEvoy|first=Jonathan|title=Queens Park Strangers: F1 chief Bernie Ecclestone says Flavio Briatore ban is harsh – and that he no longer talks to him|work=The Daily Mail|location=London|date=25 September 2009|accessdate=29 September 2009}}</ref>
==Reaction== After Renault F1 were formally charged, the alleged offence was thought to be unprecedented within Formula One.<ref name=Guardian4Sep09/> The scandal followed two recent Formula One cheating scandals: a case of [[2007 Formula One espionage controversy|industrial espionage between teams]] (including Renault F1); and an instance of the 2008 World Champion [[Lewis Hamilton]] being found to have [[2009 Australian Grand Prix|lied to race stewards]] in March 2009.
The scandal interrupted the team's parent company [[Renault|Renault S.A.]]'s launch of four electric vehicles at the [[Frankfurt Motor Show]] after journalists questioned Renault chief executive [[Carlos Ghosn]] over the affair, who directed all inquiries to Bernard Rey, chairman of Renault F1.<ref name=Times6837590>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6837590.ece |title=Renault fearful of dent to global brand |work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=17 September 2009|first=Adam|last=Sage}}</ref> On 17 September, [[Patrick Pelata]], [[Renault|Renault S.A.'s]] [[chief operating officer]], first representative from Renault to officially comment on the Singapore crash affair, stated that "The [Renault F1] team believes that a mistake has been made, and punishment must follow. Flavio Briatore considered himself to be morally responsible and resigned" and that the team would defer making a decision on the future options for the team.<ref name=Times17Sep09Pelata>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6838334.ece|title=Renault chief admits 'Crashgate' has damaged company |work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009|first=Robert|last=Dineen}}</ref> Pelata added that he did not wish the actions of Briatore and Symonds to "reflect upon the whole company and the entire Formula 1 team".<ref name=BBC17Sep09Blame>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8261004.stm|title=Renault blames Briatore & Symonds|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref> In addition, Ghosn also called for calm and for Renault to "not react in the heat of the moment" while the Renault F1 team collaborated with the authorities, adding that "I am confident when the facts are established, we can take a very clear decision".<ref name=PA17Sep09Ghosn>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5g_coV1t_-kmy9AptfdNGF64Enf1g|title=Renault chief calls for calm|publisher=UK Press Association|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jrIs3jkZ?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5g_coV1t_-kmy9AptfdNGF64Enf1g|archivedate=17 September 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Former [[Jordan Grand Prix]] F1 team principal [[Eddie Jordan]] believed that the departure of Briatore and Symonds from Renault on 16 September was an effective admission of guilt.<ref name=BBC16Sep09RenaultStatement/> Former three-time Formula One World Champion and [[Stewart Grand Prix|former team]] owner Sir [[Jackie Stewart]] said of the Singapore scandal that "There is something fundamentally rotten and wrong at the heart of Formula One. Never in my experience has Formula One been in such a mood of self-destruction. Millions of fans are amazed, if not disgusted, at a sport which now goes from crisis to crisis with everyone blaming everyone else."<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09Reactions>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/renault/6201778/Singapore-crash-what-they-are-saying.html|title=Singapore crash: what they are saying|publisher=The Telegraph|location=London|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref> Former three-time Formula One World Champion and former [[Jaguar Racing]] team manager [[Niki Lauda]], while comparing the Singapore incident to the [[2007 Formula One espionage controversy|2007 espionage scandal]], declared that "This [the Singapore crash incident], though, is new. The biggest damage ever. Now the FIA must punish Renault heavily to restore credibility in the sport."<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09Reactions/> Former 1996 F1 World Champion [[Damon Hill]] described the Singapore crash as "not a very good episode" for the sport and said of the future of F1 that "I'm concerned the sport is going to suffer as a genuine challenge, which is what I always felt it should be and would like it to be, of skill and competitiveness".<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09Reactions/> Former racing driver [[Eddie Irvine]], who retired from Formula One at the end of 2002, believed that the response to the Singapore incident had been an overreaction, stating that "This [Singapore incident] is probably slightly on the wrong side of the cheating thing but in days past every team have done whatever they could to win – cheat, bend the rules, break the rules, sabotage opponents", "[t]his is just the FIA going on a crusade". He also speculated that the FIA would be lenient on Renault F1 and not expel them, due to the sport's current "shaky" condition after recent team departures.<ref name=BBC17Sep09Irvine>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8260479.stm|title=Teams do anything to win – Irvine|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref>
Chief Sportswriter [[Simon Barnes]] of British newspaper ''[[The Times]]'' sparked debate over the incident when he labelled it "the worst single piece of cheating in the history of sport" primarily because of its "potentially lethal consequences" to Piquet, the other drivers, marshals and spectators.<ref name=Times17Sep09Barnes>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6837713.ece|title=The worst act of cheating in the history of sport|work=The Times|location=London|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|first=Simon|last=Barnes}}</ref><ref name=Times18Sep09Comparison>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6839134.ece |title=Are Renault really the worst villains?|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|first1=Anushka|last1=Asthana|first2=Jill|last2=Sherman}}</ref> Supporting Barnes, ''The Times''' motor racing correspondent Edward Gorman cited the alleged top level pre-conceived elements of conspiracy that sought to sacrifice one team member to benefit another to put the incident on a par with controversies such as [[Ben Johnson (sprinter)|Ben Johnson]], [[List of doping cases in sport#Horses|horse doping]] and illegal keels used in the [[America's Cup]]. Gorman then postulated that this incident was worse than those because Briatore and Symonds set in motion "an event of violent destruction, the consequences of which they could neither predict nor control."<ref name=Times18Sep09Comparison/> [[Matthew Syed]] countered that while the incident was premeditated, "unspeakably unethical" and dangerous, it was not nearly as reckless as the [[Doping in East Germany|East German athletics doping scandal]] and other instances of long-term doping. Syed also argued that the Renault team would not have been expecting injuries to result from the crash, in contrast to incidents such as the assault on ice skater [[Nancy Kerrigan]].<ref name=Times18Sep09Comparison/>
Responding to Flavio Briatore's resignation from Renault F1, [[Formula One Management|Formula One Management's]] [[Bernie Ecclestone]] stated that "It is a pity that Flavio has ended his Formula One career in this way", "You can't defend him at all. What he did was completely unnecessary. It's a pity that it's happened", although Ecclestone denied that the scandal would 'finish' the sport, citing the sport's recovery from the [[death of Ayrton Senna]] and the retirement of seven-time World Champion [[Michael Schumacher]].<ref name=Eurosport17Sep09Sacrifice>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/17092009/2/briatore-says-sacrificed-himself-team.html|title=Briatore says he sacrificed himself for team|publisher=''Yahoo! Eurosport UK & Ireland|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=17 September 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jrMszCXY?url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/17092009/2/briatore-says-sacrificed-himself-team.html|archivedate=17 September 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Main sponsors leave Renault F1=== [[File:Renault after losing the title sponsor ING 2009 Japan.jpg|thumb|Renault equipment on the pitwall at the [[2009 Japanese Grand Prix]] with ING logos covered after the company ended their sponsorship.]] In response to the scandal, Renault's main sponsors [[ING Group|ING]] and [[Mutua Madrileña]] ended their sponsorship agreements with Renault early, within a week after the FIA's decision and right before the next race, the [[2009 Singapore Grand Prix]], with the team removing their logos from the cars before the event.<ref name="autosportsponsors">{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/78841|title=Renault removes ING, Mutua logos|work=autosport.com|publisher=Haymarket Publications|first=Pablo|last=Elizalde|date=25 September 2009|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
Major sponsor Mutua Madrileña withdrew its sponsorship of the Renault F1 team first, just before the 2009 Singapore Grand Prix weekend, believing that the situation "could affect the image, reputation and good name of the team's sponsors."<ref name="BBCMutua">{{cite news |title=Briatore ban too harsh – F1 boss |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8272812.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> Mutua Madrileña did not withdraw sponsorship of Renault driver [[Fernando Alonso]], as he was not implicated in the scandal.<ref name="MutuaReuters">{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Iain|title=Spanish insurer cancels Renault sponsorship|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idCATRE58N47R20090924|publisher=Reuters|date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> This was followed hours later by the withdrawal of title sponsor [[ING Group]] with immediate effect, who had been previously due to end their sponsorship of the team at the end of 2009.<ref name=Motorsport.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=346518&FS=F1|title=Title sponsor ING axes Renault backing |publisher=Motorsport.com|date=7 October 2009|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
===Flavio Briatore's response=== On 19 October 2009, Flavio Briatore announced his intentions to sue the FIA for his lifetime ban, claiming that "the FIA [had] been used as a tool of vengeance on behalf of one man" and that there were several miscarriages of justice, including a delay in summons, a failure to state the charges in advance and a lack of access to documents and "Witness X".<ref>{{cite news|title=Briatore takes FIA to court|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/79569|first=Jonathan|last=Noble|date=18 October 2009|accessdate=19 October 2009|work=autosport.com|publisher=Haymarket Publications}}</ref> On 5 January 2010, the French [[Tribunal d'instance|Tribunal de Grande Instance]] overturned his ban, and awarded him €15,000 in compensation.<ref name="Courtoverturns"/> Symonds' ban was also overturned, and he was awarded €5,000 in compensation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gorman|first=Edward|title=FIA considering appeal after bans on Flavio Briatore and Pat Symonds lifted|work=The Times|location=London|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6977111.ece|date=6 January 2010|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> Briatore was believed to be suing the FIA for damages in addition to getting his ban overturned, and has also stated his intention to pursue legal action against the Piquet family.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lostia|first=Michele|author2=Beer, Matt |title=Briatore plans action against Piquets|publisher=Haymarket Publications|work=autosport.com|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/80750|date=6 January 2010|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref>
===FIA appeal=== On 11 January 2010, the FIA announced that they would appeal the decision of the Tribunal de Grande Instance to overturn the bans imposed on Flavio Briatore and Pat Symonds. The FIA reinstated the bans while the appeal was active, but stated that drivers managed by Briatore would be granted their superlicences for 2010.<ref name=BBC8452410>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8452410.stm |title=FIA to appeal against decision to Flavio Briatore ban|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 January 2010 |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> On 12 April, the FIA announced a settlement with Briatore and Symonds, and that the legal action had been ended. Both men agreed not to work in Formula One until 2013, nor any other FIA-sanctioned championship until the end of 2011.<ref name=settlement/>
===Libel case against Renault=== On 7 December 2010 it was announced that Nelson Piquet Jr and his father had won a libel case against Renault at the High Court based on the allegations described above. Renault apologised to the Piquets and paid them substantial damages. Admitting they libelled the duo, a Renault statement read: "The team accepts, as it did before the World Motor Sport Council, that the allegations made by Nelson Piquet Junior were not false. As a result, these serious allegations contained in our press release were wholly untrue and unfounded, and we withdraw them unequivocally. We would like to apologise unreservedly to Mr Piquet Junior and his father for the distress and embarrassment caused as a result. As a mark of the sincerity of our apology and regret, we have agreed to pay them a substantial amount of damages for libel as well as their costs, and have undertaken not to repeat these allegations at any time in the future. It also accepts that Mr Piquet Junior and his father did not invent these allegations to blackmail the team into allowing him to drive for them for the remainder of the 2009 season."<ref name="Piquetwinlibelcase"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/SPORT/motorsport/12/07/motorsport.piquet.renault.apology/index.html|title=Piquet duo win libel case over Renault|publisher=CNN|date=7 December 2010|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
==Potential consequences== {{update|section|date=January 2010}} It was suggested in the media that if Briatore were personally found guilty of race-fixing, he might fail the [[The Football League|English Football League]]'s [[Fit and proper person test]] which applies to football club owners and directors, whose regulations exclude people who are "subject to a ban from a sports governing body relating to the administration of their sport", though a BBC report opined that his position might be secure given that he had left Renault.<ref name="Footbal League Briatore"/> The Football League stated that they would wait for the conclusion of the investigation before examining Briatore's fitness to continue to be a director of [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]].<ref name=Times6837747>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/formula_1/article6837747.ece |title=‘Crashgate’ could force QPR to find new owner|work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=17 September 2009|date=17 September 2009 |first1=Russell|last1=Kempson|first2=Gary|last2=Jacob}}</ref> The Football League board discussed the matter on 8 October 2009 and declared that they would be awaiting a response from Briatore to various questions before commenting further.<ref name=BBC8Oct09Briatore>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8295331.stm|title=Briatore's QPR fate put on hold|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 October 2009|accessdate=8 October 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kNURUzte?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8295331.stm|archivedate=8 October 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In addition to any sporting sanctions by the FIA, Renault, Piquet Jr. or even Felipe Massa could take legal action over the incident.<ref name=Telegraph17Sep09QnA/> It was speculated by the media that Briatore and Symonds could be [[Extradition|extradited]] to Singapore to face criminal charges relating to the incident, which according to one lawyer could encompass "causing malicious or willful damage to property, endangering a vehicle and criminal conspiracy to commit a serious crime".<ref name=Guardian18Sep09Extradition>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/sep/18/renault-flavio-briatore-formula-one|title=Singapore unlikely to extradite Flavio Briatore and Pat Symonds|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=2009-09-18}}</ref><ref name=SingaporeBT20Sep09Extradition>{{cite web |url=http://motoring.asiaone.com/Motoring/Motorworld/Story/A1Story20090918-168654.html |title=Disgraced F1 pair could face S'pore extradition |work=Business Times|location=Singapore|date=20 September 2009|accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref> This was thought to be unlikely however, with the Singaporean authorities believed to be unwilling to attract the negative publicity charges it would create, and also complicated by the fact that Singapore has an extradition treaty with the United Kingdom (Symonds being a British citizen) but not [[Italy]] (Briatore being an Italian citizen).<ref name=Guardian18Sep09Extradition/>
Piquet Jr. was criticised by many in the community and some suggest that the controversy effectively ended his hopes of continuing in F1. [[BBC]] F1 commentator [[Martin Brundle]] suggested that Piquet Jr. was now unemployable in Formula One, saying that no team or sponsor would want to be associated with the Piquet family. Brundle noted that Piquet Jr. "didn't deliver at Renault, he wasn't fast enough, that's why he was released and that's why he has dropped hand grenades into the system ever since". Brundle was also highly critical that Piquet Jr. escaped sanction from the FIA despite admitting to race-fixing, while the others involved were heavily punished.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brundle|first=Martin|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8254417.stm |title=Piquet 'now unemployable in F1'|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 September 2009|accessdate=23 September 2009}}</ref><ref name="mirror1">{{cite web|last=Ferdinand|first=Dan|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/motorsport/2009/09/22/nelson-piquet-can-expect-a-paddock-backlash-for-deliberately-crashing-his-renault-at-last-year-s-singapore-grand-prix-115875-21691484/|title=Nelson Piquet can expect a paddock backlash for deliberately crashing his Renault at last year's Singapore Grand Prix|work=Daily Mirror|location=London|date=11 August 2009 |accessdate=23 September 2009}}</ref> Other leading F1 figures have echoed Brundle's sentiments. Toyota team principal John Howett was quoted as saying, "I think on his performance...disregarding the issue, I probably would not give him a drive and I would probably be further influenced in that decision by what took place." Christian Horner, team principal of Red Bull Racing, has added, "I don't think we would have any interest [in Piquet Jr.] at Red Bull Racing."<ref name="Little support for Nelson Piquet">{{cite web|url=http://en.f1-live.com/f1/en/headlines/news/detail/091002121925.shtml |title=Little support for Nelson Piquet |publisher=F1-Live.com |date=2 October 2009 |accessdate=3 October 2009}}</ref>
Piquet Jr. has since joined America's NASCAR circuit, starting in the Camping World Truck Series and Nationwide Series in 2010. He drove for Turner Scott Motorsports part-time in the #30 Chevrolet Silverado in the Camping World Truck Series and full-time in the #30 Chevrolet Camaro in the Nationwide Series. In 2014-2015 Piquet Jr. took part in the inaugural [[Formula E]] season with [[China Racing]], eventually becoming Formula E's inaugural champion by a single point over [[Sébastien Buemi]].
==See also== * [[1994 Formula One cheating controversy|Allegations of cheating in the 1994 Formula One season]] * [[2007 Formula One espionage controversy]] * [[2008 Formula One season]] * [[2008 Singapore Grand Prix]] * [[2009 Formula One season]] * [[2013 Federated Auto Parts 400]], another case of a driver intentionally causing a safety car to manipulate the results of the race * [[List of scandals with "-gate" suffix]] * [[List of sporting scandals]]

molecular_weight = 463.79 g/mol | smiles = O=C(NN1CCCCC1)c4nn(c2ccc(Cl)cc2Cl)c(c3ccc(Cl)cc3)c4C | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C22H21Cl3N4O/c1-14-20(22(30)27-28-11-3-2-4-12-28)26-29(19-10-9-17(24)13-18(19)25)21(14)15-5-7-16(23)8-6-15/h5-10,13H,2-4,11-12H2,1H3,(H,27,30) | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = JZCPYUJPEARBJL-UHFFFAOYSA-N }} '''Rimonabant''' (also known as '''SR141716'''; trade names '''Acomplia''', '''Zimulti'''){{cite web|title=Rimonabant|url=http://adisinsight.springer.com/drugs/800007737|publisher=AdisInsight|accessdate=21 February 2017|language=en}} is an [[anorectic]] [[anti-obesity|antiobesity drug]] that was first approved in Europe in 2006 but was withdrawn worldwide in 2008 due to serious psychiatric side effects; it was never approved in the United States.{{cite journal|last1=Sam|first1=AH|last2=Salem|first2=V|last3=Ghatei|first3=MA|title=Rimonabant: From RIO to Ban.|journal=Journal of Obesity|date=2011|volume=2011|pages=432607|pmid=21773005|pmc=3136184|doi=10.1155/2011/432607}}{{cite journal|last1=Moreira|first1=FA|last2=Crippa|first2=JA|title=The psychiatric side-effects of rimonabant.|journal=Revista brasileira de psiquiatria (Sao Paulo, Brazil : 1999)|date=June 2009|volume=31|issue=2|pages=145–53|pmid=19578688|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1516-44462009000200012|doi=10.1590/s1516-44462009000200012}} Rimonabant is an [[inverse agonist]] for the [[cannabinoid receptor CB1]] and was the first drug approved in that class.{{cite journal |vauthors=Fong TM, Heymsfield SB |title= Cannabinoid-1 receptor inverse agonists: current understanding of mechanism of action and unanswered questions |journal= Int J Obes (Lond) |volume= 33 |issue= 9 |pages= 947–55 |date=September 2009 |pmid= 19597516 |doi= 10.1038/ijo.2009.132 }}{{cite news|title=European Approval Comes Early for Sanofi-Aventis' Acomplia|url=https://www.ihs.com/country-industry-forecasting.html?ID=106599233|work=IHS|date=June 23, 2006}} ==History== {{See also|Discovery and development of Cannabinoid Receptor 1 Antagonists}} Rimonabant is a selective CB1 [[receptor (biochemistry)|receptor]] blocker and was [[drug discovery|discovered]] and [[drug development|developed]] by [[Sanofi|Sanofi-Aventis]];{{Citation | last = Barth | first = F. | last2 =Rinaldi-Carmona | first2 = M. | title = The Development of Cannabinoid Antagonists| journal =Current Medicinal Chemistry| volume = 6 | pages = 745–755| year = 1999 | url=http://www.bentham.org/cmc/contabs/vol6-8.html | pmid = 10469889 | issue = 8 }} On 21 June 2006, the [[European Commission]] approved the sale of rimonabant in the then-25-member European Union as a prescription drug for use in conjunction with diet and exercise for patients with a [[body mass index|body mass index (BMI)]] greater than 30 kg/m², or patients with a BMI greater than 27 kg/m² with associated risk factors, such as type 2 [[diabetes]] or [[dyslipidaemia]].{{cite web|title=Acomplia EPAR|url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/docs/en_GB/document_library/EPAR_-_Summary_for_the_public/human/000666/WC500021282.pdf|publisher=EMA|date=January 30, 2009}} From [http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/medicines/human/medicines/000666/human_med_000623.jsp EMA index page] It was first in its class to be approved anywhere in the world. Rimonabant was submitted to the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) for approval in the United States in 2005; in 2007, the FDA's Endocrine and Metabolic Drugs Advisory Committee (EMDAC) concluded that Sanofi-Aventis failed to demonstrate the safety of rimonabant and voted against recommending the anti-obesity treatment for approval{{cite news|last1=Saul|first1=Stephanie|title=F.D.A. Panel Rejects Drug for Obesity|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE7D9143FF937A25755C0A9619C8B63|work=The New York Times|date=14 June 2007}} and two weeks later the company withdrew the application.{{cite news|title=Sanofi-Aventis Drops Application for Drug|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/30/business/30drug.html|work=The New York Times|date=30 June 2007}} The drug was approved in Brazil in April 2007. In October 2008, the [[European Medicines Agency]] recommended the suspension of Acomplia after the [[Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use]] (CHMP) had determined that the risks of Acomplia [[risk-benefit analysis|outweighed its benefits]] due to the risk of serious psychiatric problems, including suicide.{{cite web |url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/news_and_events/news/2009/11/news_detail_000244.jsp|title=The European Medicines Agency recommends suspension of the marketing authorisation of Acomplia|publisher=European Medicines Agency|date=23 October 2008|accessdate=18 January 2016}} In November 2008 an advisory committee in Brazil recommended suspension as well, and that month Sanofi-Aventis suspended sale of the drug worldwide. The EMA approval was withdrawn in January 2009.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/7687311.stm|title=Anti-obesity drug use suspended|date=23 October 2008|work=BBC News|accessdate=4 March 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/docs/en_GB/document_library/Public_statement/2009/11/WC500012189.pdf |title=Public Statement on Acomplia (rimonabant) Withdrawal of the Marketing Authorisation in the European Union|publisher=European Medicines Agency |date=30 January 2009 |accessdate=18 January 2016}} In 2009 India prohibited the manufacture and sale of the drug.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdsco.nic.in/writereaddata/DBC.pdfl|title=Drugs banned in India|publisher=Central Drugs Standard Control Organization, Dte.GHS, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India|accessdate=2013-09-17}} ==Adverse effects== Data from clinical trials submitted to regulatory authorities showed that rimonabant caused depressive disorders or mood alterations in up to 10% of subjects and suicidal ideation in around 1%, and in Europe it was contraindicated for people with any psychiatric disorder, including depressed or suicidal individuals. Additionally, nausea and upper respiratory tract infections were very common (occurring in more than 10% of people) adverse effects; common adverse effects (occurring in between 1% and 10% of people) included [[gastroenteritis]], anxiety, irritability, insomnia and other sleep disorders, hot flushes, diarrhea, vomiting, dry or itchy skin, tendonitis, muscle cramps and spasms, fatigue, flu-like symptoms, and increased risk of falling. The FDA's advisory committee raised concerns that based on animal data, it appeared that the [[therapeutic window]] with regard to CNS toxicity, and specifically seizures was almost nonexistent; the therapeutic dose and the dose that caused seizures in animals appeared to be the same.{{cite web|title=FDA Briefing Document NDA 21-888 Zimulti (rimonabant) Tablets, 20|url=https://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/07/briefing/2007-4306b1-fda-backgrounder.pdf|publisher=FDA|date=June 13, 2007}}{{cite web|last1=Davis-Bruno|first1=Karen|title=Nonclinical Overview: CNS Toxicity with Rimonabant|url=http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/07/slides/2007-4306s1-09-FDA-Bruno.ppt|publisher=FDA, Division of Metabolism & Endocrinology Products|date=June 13, 2007}} When the EMA reviewed [[postmarketing surveillance]] data, it found that the risk of psychiatric disorders in people taking rimonabant was doubled. ==Chemistry== The chemical synthesis of rimonabant is described as follows:{{Cite journal |doi= 10.1021/jm00122a022 |title= Studies on hindered phenols and analogs. 1. Hypolipidemic and hypoglycemic agents with ability to inhibit lipid peroxidation |year= 1989 |author= Yoshioka, T.|journal= Journal of Medicinal Chemistry |volume= 32 |pages= 421–8 |pmid= 2913302 |issue= 2 |display-authors=etal}} [[File:Rimonabant.png|600px]] == Research == Along with the clinical trials in obesity that generated the data submitted to regulatory authorities,{{cite journal | vauthors = Pi-Sunyer FX, Aronne LJ, Heshmati HM, Devin J, Rosenstock J | date = Feb 2006 | title = Effect of rimonabant, a cannabinoid-1 receptor blocker, on weight and cardiometabolic risk factors in overweight or obese patients: RIO-North America: a randomized controlled trial | url = | journal = JAMA | volume = 295 | issue = 7| pages = 761–75 | doi = 10.1001/jama.295.7.761 | pmid = 16478899 }} rimonabant was also studied in clinical trials as a potential treatment for other conditions, including diabetes, atherosclerosis, and smoking cessation.{{cite journal|last1=Cahill|first1=K|last2=Ussher|first2=MH|title=Cannabinoid type 1 receptor antagonists for smoking cessation.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=16 March 2011|issue=3|pages=CD005353|pmid=21412887|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD005353.pub4}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Maldonado R, Valverde O, Berrendero F |title=Involvement of the endocannabinoid system in drug addiction |journal=Trends Neurosci. |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=225–32 |year=2006 |pmid=16483675 |doi=10.1016/j.tins.2006.01.008 }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Antiobesity preparations}} {{Cannabinoids}} {{Cannabinoidergics}} {{Opioidergics}} [[Category:Hydrazides]] [[Category:Anorectics]] [[Category:Anxiogenics]] [[Category:CB1 receptor antagonists]] [[Category:Chloroarenes]] [[Category:Piperidines]] [[Category:Pyrazoles]] [[Category:Withdrawn drugs]] [[Category:Cannabinoids]] [[Category:Pyrazolecarboxamides]] [[Category:Opioid antagonists]]

{{Infobox military person | rank = [[Major]] | name = Robert A. Lewis | image=Robert_A._Lewis.jpg | caption=Capt. Lewis, c. 1945 | birth_date= {{Birth date|1917|10|18}} | birth_place=[[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], New York | death_date= {{death date and age|1983|06|18|1917|10|18}} | death_place=[[Newport News, Virginia|Newport News]], Virginia | allegiance = United States of America | branch = [[United States Army Air Forces]] | unit= [[509th Composite Group]] | battles=[[World War II]] | awards=[[Silver Star]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=48375 |title=Robert A. Lewis |website=valor.militarytimes.com |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> | laterwork = [[Chemist]], [[Manager]], [[Aviator|Pilot]] | spouse=Mary Eileen Kelly }}
'''Robert Alvin Lewis''' (October 18, 1917 – June 18, 1983) was a [[United States Army Air Forces]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] serving in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific Theatre]] during [[World War II]]. He was the [[co-pilot]] of the ''[[Enola Gay]]'', the [[B-29 Superfortress]] bomber which dropped the [[Nuclear weapon|atomic bomb]] [[Little Boy]] on the Japanese city of [[Hiroshima]] on 6 August 1945.
== Military career == {{more footnotes|section|date=July 2017}} Lewis grew up in [[Ridgefield Park, New Jersey|Ridgefield Park]], New Jersey, and attended [[Ridgefield Park High School]], graduating in 1937.<ref>{{cite web |last=Fosdick |first=George |url=https://sites.google.com/site/ridgefieldparkalumni/calendar |title=History of Ridgefield Park High School |publisher=Ridgefield Park Jr. / Sr. High School Alumni Association |accessdate=February 12, 2008}}</ref> During World War II, he had to wait after enlisting to be processed into the USAAF [[Officer Candidate School]] (OCS). Lewis went on to be a multi-engine [[test pilot]] in [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator|B-24]], [[Martin B-26 Marauder|B-26]], [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress|B-17]] and B-29 bombers, which later led to him as co-pilot and his crew being selected for the Hiroshima bombing mission.
Lewis was [[Battlefield promotion|field promoted]] to [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]] by General [[Curtis LeMay]] after demonstrating the B-29 and training the general on how to fly it. LeMay addressed Lieutenant Lewis as "Captain Lewis" on the field at the conclusion of several days of training and testing. Lewis tried to correct the general as to his rank, but LeMay insisted on captain, with the field commission arriving several weeks later by USAAF mail to him based in the midwestern US at the time.
Lewis was always a "crew-first" pilot who survived two crashes due to electrical failure and engine failure. Articles from New York City area newspapers attested to his "cool head under stressful conditions", ultimately leading to his selection as captain of a B-29 crew. Lewis led hundreds of bombing runs from Utah to [[Salton Sea]] in California leading up to his selection with his crew by [[Colonel]] [[Paul Tibbets]]. In early June, Lewis and his co-pilot Dick McNamara flew the entire crew and support crew from Utah to [[Tinian]], in the B-29 specially modified to carry Little Boy to Japan from the huge Tinian base that General LeMay controlled from [[Guam]].
On August 6, 1945 – August 5 in the United States, due to the time difference – Lewis was the co-pilot of the ''Enola Gay'' when it dropped Little Boy on Hiroshima. Normally the aircraft commander assigned to the ''Enola Gay'', for this important mission he acted as co-pilot, assisting ''Enola Gay''<nowiki/>'s new aircraft commander, Colonel Tibbets. Lewis and his crew, minus their original co-pilot Dick McNamara, were Tibbet's crew for the mission, and it included two specialists for the arming of Little Boy, the [[uranium-235]] fission bomb.
The entire story was written by Lewis just before his death in 1983. His log, the only minute-by-minute recording on paper by any crew member that day, is part of his copyrighted historical manuscript. His sons and daughter are in the process of publishing the manuscript before the 75th anniversary of the bombing in 2020.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
== Post-war == After the war, Lewis became a pilot for [[American Overseas Airlines]],<ref name=AsburyObit>{{cite web |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12259595/robert_a_lewis_copilot_of_hiroshima/ |title=Robert A. Lewis, co-pilot of Hiroshima A-bomber |newspaper=[[Asbury Park Press]] |location=[[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]], New Jersey |date=June 20, 1983 |accessdate=July 9, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name=TimesObit/> specializing in the New York to London routes. He left in 1947 to rejoin his prewar employer, the [[Heide Candy Company|Henry Heide Candy Company]], where he became plant manager and personnel director of their factory in [[New Brunswick, New Jersey|New Brunswick]], New Jersey.<ref name=AsburyObit/> He was granted at least three patents during his time at Heide.<ref>{{cite web |title=US003097951 |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=3097951.PN.&OS=PN/3097951&RS=PN/3097951 |website=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office|USPTO]] |date=July 16, 1963 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=US003332583 |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=3332583.PN.&OS=PN/3332583&RS=PN/3332583 |website=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office|USPTO]] |date=July 25, 1967 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=US003795352 |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=3795352.PN.&OS=PN/3795352&RS=PN/3795352 |website=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office|USPTO]] |date=March 5, 1974 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> In the 1950s, Lewis lived with his family in a home that he had built in [[Old Tappan, New Jersey|Old Tappan]], New Jersey.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Lewis |first=Robert A. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ei0DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA71 |title=How We Dropped the A-Bomb |magazine=[[Popular Science]] |date=August 1957 |accessdate=May 26, 2015}}</ref> He and his wife had a daughter and four sons.<ref name=AsburyObit/><ref name=TimesObit/>
===Survivor meetings=== In [[New York City]] in 1951, Lewis met Hiroshima survivor Father [[Hubert Schiffer]],<ref name=TCA>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12345288/enola_gay_pilot_hears_bombs_amazing/ |title='Enola Gay' Pilot Hears Bomb's Amazing Effect |newspaper=The Catholic Advance |location=[[Wichita, Kansas|Wichita]], Kansas |date=January 19, 1951 |accessdate=July 13, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref> who was eight blocks from [[ground zero]] when the explosion occurred and was seriously injured.<ref name=ADS/> Schiffer invited Lewis to visit Hiroshima in August 1952 for the dedication of a "palace of prayer", which Lewis accepted;<ref name=TCA/> however, there is no record of Lewis actually making such a visit. The two also appeared together at [[Fordham University]] in 1957, on the twelfth anniversary of the bombing, with Schiffer noting that they had become "very fast friends."<ref name=ADS>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12345447/old_pals_differ_on_using_bomb/ |title=Old Pals Differ On Using Bomb |newspaper=[[Arizona Daily Star]] |location=[[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]], Arizona |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=August 7, 1957 |accessdate=July 13, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref>
In 1955, Lewis appeared on the television show ''[[This is Your Life]]'', in an episode not without controversy. The show had as its guest Reverend [[Kiyoshi Tanimoto]], who had been living in Hiroshima at the time of the bombing and survived the explosion, as recounted in [[John Hersey]]'s 1946 book ''[[Hiroshima (book)|Hiroshima]]''. Tanimoto had traveled to the United States with the [[Hiroshima Maidens]] to get reconstructive surgery for them, and while there was the subject of the May 11 episode of ''This Is Your Life.''<ref name=Parsons>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12232053/tanimoto_lewis/ |title=Hollywood Today (column) |first=Louella O. |last=Parsons |agency=[[International News Service|INS]] |newspaper=[[The Arizona Republic]] |location=[[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], Arizona |date=May 14, 1955 |accessdate=July 8, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref> After some acquaintances were introduced and interviewed, a surprise for Tanimoto was meeting Lewis – on [[live television]] broadcast to a nationwide audience – representing the crew of the aircraft that had so dramatically changed his life.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rakoff |first=David |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F06E1D71331F932A25752C0A9629C8B63&scp=4&sq=lewis+%22enola+gay%22&st=nyt |title=Theater; Hiroshima Bomber and Victims: This Is Your (Puppet's) Life |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 11, 2004 |accessdate=February 12, 2008}}</ref> Contemporary reaction to the episode was mixed, ranging from "one of [the] best"<ref name=Parsons/> to a "new low in poor taste."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conelrad.blogspot.com/2010/08/hiroshima-this-is-your-life.html |title=Hiroshima: This Is Your Life |website=conelrad.blogspot.com |date=August 6, 2010 |accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref> Lewis described the ''Enola Gay'''s flight and the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima. When asked by host [[Ralph Edwards]] if he remembered his reaction on that fateful day, he remarked, "I wrote down later, 'My God, what have we done?' "<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c_58byuLBu0&t=2m0s |title=White Light/Black Rain excerpt |via=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=July 8, 2017}}</ref>
===Later life=== Lewis became a self-taught [[Stone sculpture|stone sculptor]], working in [[marble]] and [[alabaster]], following a business trip to [[Florence]] where he saw some apprentices at work.<ref name=AsburySculpt>{{cite web |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12259890/abomb_pilot_carves_new_career/ |title=A-Bomb Pilot Carves New Career |newspaper=[[Asbury Park Press]] |location=[[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]], New Jersey |date=August 2, 1970 |accessdate=July 9, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref> One of his sculptures, titled ''‘God’s Wind’ at Hiroshima?'', depicted a [[mushroom cloud]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conelrad.blogspot.com/2010/10/shroom-odyssey-of-robert-lewiss-atomic.html |title=The 'Shroom: The Odyssey of Robert Lewis's Atomic Sculpture |website=conelrad.blogspot.com |date=October 11, 2010 |accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref> In the 1970s, Lewis lived in a small cottage on West Shore Trail in the quiet [[Lake Mohawk, New Jersey|Lake Mohawk]] community of [[Sparta, New Jersey|Sparta]], New Jersey.
In 1971, Lewis sold his manuscript log from the Hiroshima mission, which he had written during the flight at the request of journalist [[William L. Laurence]]; it was auctioned by [[Christies]] and sold for $37,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12308250/copilots_log_of_aattack_auctioned/ |title=Copilot's Log Of A-Attack Auctioned |newspaper=[[Hartford Courant]] |location=[[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]], Connecticut |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=November 27, 1971 |accessdate=July 12, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref> The manuscript was later resold to [[Malcolm Forbes]], and after Forbes' death was purchased by an anonymous buyer.<ref name=Bonhams/> Prior to the 1971 sale, Lewis made six hand-written copies of the log, one each for his wife and five children; one copy was sold in 2015 for $50,000.<ref name=Bonhams>{{cite web |url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/22456/lot/294/ |title=Lot 294 |website=[[Bonhams]] |date=April 2015 |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref>
In 1975, Lewis took a position with the Estee Candy Corporation, until his retirement in 1981.<ref name=AsburyObit/><ref name=TimesObit/> He was portrayed by [[Gregory Harrison]] in the 1980 [[television film]] ''Enola Gay: The Men, the Mission, the Atomic Bomb''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080689/ |title=Enola Gay: The Men, the Mission, the Atomic Bomb (1980) |website=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> Lewis lived in [[Smithfield, Virginia|Smithfield]], Virginia, for two years before his death in 1983 of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at home;<ref name=AsburyObit/> he was declared dead at [[Riverside Health System|Riverside Hospital]] in [[Newport News, Virginia|Newport News]], Virginia.<ref name=TimesObit>{{cite news |url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F20C15FA395F0C738EDDAF0894DB484D81 |title=Robert A. Lewis, 65, Co-pilot on Mission Over Hiroshima |first=Lindsey |last=Gruson |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 20, 1983 |accessdate=February 12, 2008}}</ref>
In 1990, Lewis' widow put up for auction a manuscript navigator's log from the Hiroshima mission, however it failed to sell after questions arose about its authenticity, with ''Enola Gay'' navigator [[Theodore Van Kirk]] stating that he still had the log he wrote during the mission.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12308422/enola_gay_flight_log_fails_to_sell/ |title=Enola Gay flight log fails to sell |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |location=[[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], Florida |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=December 8, 1990 |accessdate=July 12, 2017 |via=newspapers.com}}</ref>
